Patient Name: N/A
Gender: Female
Age: 71
Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A
Admission Diagnosis: N/A
Discharge Diagnosis: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the neurology department with symptoms of muscle pain and weakness after being on Palbociclib for 21 days. Blood samples showed increased creatine kinase with elevated levels of plasma-myoglobin. The patient's MRI revealed edema in multiple muscle groups, which indicated muscular necrosis.

During the hospitalization, a diagnostic panel for detecting myositis-specific and myositis-associated autoantibodies was conducted. However, the results were not contributory. To prevent kidney injury, the patient received intravenous saline, and a trial of intravenous immunoglobulin was initiated, suspecting an autoimmune etiology for the muscle injury. The patient gradually recovered over 2 weeks and was discharged to outpatient rehabilitation. The patient was seen at the neuromuscular outpatient clinic approximately one year after hospitalization, showing no signs of neuro-muscular deficit.

Summary of Findings:
The patient was a 71-year-old woman who presented with symptoms of muscle pain and weakness after being on Palbociclib for 21 days. Blood and MRI test results showed increased creatine kinase with elevated levels of plasma-myoglobin and edema in multiple muscle groups, which indicated muscular necrosis. A diagnostic panel for detecting myositis-specific and myositis-associated autoantibodies was conducted, and a muscle biopsy was obtained. Heterozygous presence of the common SNP rs4149056 in the SLCO1B1 gene was detected.

Plan:
The patient was hydrated with intravenous saline to prevent kidney injury and received a trial of intravenous immunoglobulin. The muscle biopsy showed atrophy without signs of cell necrosis, mononuclear cell infiltration, HLA-ABC-positive fibers, regenerated fibers, or ragged-red fibers. The patient recovered gradually over 2 weeks and was discharged to outpatient rehabilitation. A follow-up visit was scheduled at the neuromuscular outpatient clinic.

Hospital Course:
A Caucasian boy was born by spontaneous vaginal delivery to a 29-year-old gravida 1, para 1 mother at 39 1/7 weeks of gestation. The neonate displayed a good adaptation to extrauterine life, but a complete cord blood count revealed a severe thrombocytopenia which was confirmed by a venous blood sample. 
At 24 hours of life, he developed apneas and periodic breathing requiring oxygen flow and short bag-mask ventilation. Brain imaging showed large heterogeneous right temporo-parieto-occipital and small left occipital lesions, suggestive of intracranial hemorrhage predominant within the right hemisphere. Bedside electroencephalography monitoring revealed multifocal electrical seizures starting from the left occipital lobe, and treatment with phenobarbital was started. 
During the first 17 days of life, the patient received 6 platelet transfusions and 6 intravenous injections of immunoglobulins. The child was discharged at 17 days of life with a normal neurological status, and his last platelet count was 70 G/L. Phenobarbital was stopped before discharge. 
At the last follow-up at 12 months of life, the child exhibited normal psychomotor development and unremarkable neurological status.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission:
Mr. X, a 70-year-old gentleman with a history of aortic mechanical prosthetic valve implantation, was admitted to the emergency department with pain and swelling in the right leg. The patient had suffered blunt injury to the leg a week prior.

Clinical Findings:
On examination, the patient displayed a swollen, ecchymotic, and tense lateral compartment of the leg, with palpable distal pulses. A Doppler ultrasound showed a large intramuscular hematoma in the lateral compartment of the leg, with leakage of a muscle branch of the anterior tibial artery.

Treatment:
Initial treatment included an ultrasound-guided compression of the artery in the PA for 24 hours, but this was unsuccessful. Subsequently, the patient underwent thrombin injection into the PA, which resulted in a successful thrombosis of the sac. A repeat arterial Doppler was conducted 24 and 48 hours post-treatment, which showed no further arterial leaks.

Diagnosis:
Intramuscular hematoma in the lateral compartment of the right leg due to blunt trauma.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Instructions:
The patient was advised to follow up with their primary care physician and monitor their leg for any additional swelling or pain. No further interventions were necessary.

Summary:
Mr. X was admitted with a large hematoma in the lateral compartment of the right leg due to blunt trauma. Thrombin injection into the affected artery was successful and the patient was discharged in stable condition without further interventions.

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Redacted]     Medical Record Number: [Redacted]     Date of Admission: [Redacted]     Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient is an Hispanic female born at 32 weeks of gestation to a G2P1 mother through spontaneous vaginal delivery. The patient’s amniotic fluid was observed to contain meconium. Upon physical examination, the patient’s weight was measured to be 2280 g (85th centile), length 48 cm (95th centile), and head circumference 29 cm (40th centile). Stool appeared as sticky and white at the age of 48 hours. An UGI series and a Gastrografin enema revealed jejunal atresia and microcolon. Exploratory laparotomy was performed on the patient on day 3, during which a jejunal segment was resected and a tapering enteroplasty was done. The patient’s postoperative course was uneventful.

HOSPITAL COURSE AND TREATMENT:
The patient was diagnosed with jejunal atresia and microcolon. Exploratory laparotomy with jejunal segmental resection and tapering enteroplasty was performed, followed by a three-day hospital stay. The patient was discharged in good general condition on day 31 of hospitalization.

RESULTS:
The patient had an UGI series and a Gastrografin enema with jejunal atresia and microcolon observed.

CONCLUSION:
The patient was diagnosed with jejunal atresia and microcolon, for which exploratory laparotomy with jejunal segmental resection and tapering enteroplasty was performed. The surgical intervention was successful, and the patient’s postoperative course was uneventful. The patient was discharged from the hospital on day 31 of hospitalization in good general condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 24-year-old, unmarried woman diagnosed with PTB

Admission Date: August-2013

Discharge Date: N/A (Patient still undergoing treatment)

Reason for Admission:
The patient presented with a complaint of severe cough with expectoration, evening raise of temperature, gradual weight loss, and loss of appetite since two weeks. Upon examination, the patient was diagnosed with PTB.

Hospital Course:
The patient was referred for sputum-FME, which suggested the NSP, 2+ PTB. The patient was then enrolled in the hospital's Revised National Tuberculosis Program. The institutional ethics committee of our college of medical sciences and hospital approved the study protocol, and a written informed consent form was obtained from the subject.

Recommendations:
The patient continues to receive treatment at the hospital's Revised National Tuberculosis Program and will continue to do so until the condition is satisfactorily treated. The patient is advised to follow all treatment protocols as recommended by the hospital and to adopt a healthy lifestyle by maintaining a well-balanced diet and avoiding stress.

Follow-Up:
The patient will be regularly monitored for progress in treatment of PTB. Further tests and examinations will be conducted periodically to ensure the patient's well-being.

HOSPITAL COURSE AND DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient C, a 39-year-old female with Class IV obesity and vitamin B12 deficiency, was admitted to the medical weight management program. The patient experienced weight gain during the bariatric surgical workup, being unable to adhere to the bariatric nutrition plan and physical activity plan prescribed by the surgical team. As a result, she was started on topiramate 25 mg to reduce overall hunger drive. The medication was adjusted to 50 mg after five months to combat an increase in hunger drive and was further increased to 75 mg after 15 months due to a similar reason.

Patient C lost a total of 56.70 kg (36% TBWL) after taking topiramate for 22 months, resulting in a BMI of 35.4 kg/m². The weight loss with topiramate was similar to the projected weight loss of RYGB as predicted by the MBSAQIP risk calculator. The patient denied any side effects of cognitive dullness, paresthesia, or dysgeusia during the treatment.

The patient's medical challenges included increased appetite, carbohydrate cravings, and depressive symptoms related to her weight. Her blood chemistry review at the time of initial bariatric consult showed high triglycerides and low HDL cholesterol levels that improved during the treatment period. She was unable to follow the physical activity plan due to time restrictions. Review of the patient's medication list showed no obesogenic medications contributing to weight gain. She was weight loss medication-naïve before starting the treatment.

As a result of the robust weight loss, her surgical workup was put on hold. The patient was educated on the importance of a healthy lifestyle and regular physical activity to maintain her weight loss progress achieved by the medication. The patient was also advised to continue her follow-ups with the medical weight management program.

In summary, Patient C's medical challenges related to her weight were successfully managed with topiramate. The patient achieved significant weight loss, leading to BMI reduction and improvement in blood chemistry levels. The medication was tolerated well, and the patient did not experience any side effects. The patient was discharged with appropriate counseling and follow-up plans.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not provided
Age: 37
Gender: Female
Admission Date: September 2011
Discharge Date: Not applicable

Admission Diagnosis: Snake bite by Russell's viper

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the medical casualty ward with fang marks on the 5th toe of her left foot after being bitten by a Russell's viper. The bedside test of 20 min Whole Blood Clotting time (20 min WBCT) was normal. She was given acetaminophen, Intravenous (IV) Antibiotics, IV Normal saline slow drip, and Tetanus toxoid. The baseline investigations were unremarkable. The 20 min WBCT was repeated, and it was prolonged. The Indian polyvalent snake anti venom serum (AVS) was given, but she developed retrosternal tightening chest pain, faintness, and vomiting. AVS therapy was repeated due to frequent hypotension and prolonged 20 min WBCT. The patient eventually went into cardiogenic shock and had an acute myocardial infarction with ST elevation on inferior leads. She was started on IV dopamine infusion, and thrombolysis, anticoagulants and antiplatelets were not considered due to prolonged 20 min WBCT. She had excessive puncture site bleeding but no other bleeding manifestation. Coagulation profile that was done 4 hours after myocardial infarction revealed prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (APTT). Troponin I was elevated. Due to frequent hypotension and prolonged 20 min WBCT AVS therapy was repeated. She was transferred to the Intensive care unit and assisted ventilation was given. Repeat Laboratory investigations showed a high white blood cell count with neutrophilia. The patient's blood pressure became further unstable, and asystole occurred, and cardiopulmonary resuscitation was not successful.

Discharge Instruction:

The patient passed away, and there is no discharge instruction.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [redacted]
Age: 64
Sex: Male
Hospital: [redacted]
Admission: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the hospital with a ten-year history of mild diffuse abdominal pain and anorexia. The physical examination showed a mass in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen that was mobile. A CT scan of the abdomen showed a non-enhancing mass near the small bowel. The patient underwent laparotomy during which a solid mass was discovered at the root of the jejunal mesentery. The mass was completely removed, and due to bowel ischemia, a second laparotomy was performed three days later, in which an additional segment of the small bowel was resected. The patient recovered well and was discharged one week after the second laparotomy.

Diagnosis:
Fibromatosis of the jejunum and mesentery.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with a ten-year history of mild diffuse abdominal pain and anorexia. A physical examination showed a mobile mass in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen, and a CT scan of the abdomen showed a non-enhancing mass near the small bowel. During a laparotomy procedure, a solid mass was found at the root of the jejunal mesentery that was totally excised with a loop of jejunum. However, the patient suffered from bowel ischemia necessitating a second operation that involved an additional resection of a small bowel segment. A primary anastomosis was performed, and the patient was discharged one week after the second laparotomy.

Diagnosis Summary:
The patient was diagnosed with fibromatosis of the jejunum and mesentery. A final tissue diagnosis showed spindle-shaped fibroblasts with elongated nuclei and a benign appearance that had infiltrated the muscularis propria and had non-infiltrating margins. The tumor cells were negative for antibodies to CD117, S100, CD34, and smooth muscle actin, and positive for desmin. After six months of resection, a CT scan of the abdomen showed no evidence of residual or recurrent tumor, and the patient had no evidence of disease at follow-up 16 months after surgery.

Disposition Summary:
The patient was discharged from the hospital one week after the second laparotomy and was advised to follow up with his primary care physician. The discharge instructions included taking prescribed medications as directed, resuming regular activities gradually, and scheduling follow-up appointments with the physician as instructed.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]
Patient Name: [Patient Name]
Age: 79 years
Sex: Male
Medical Record Number: [MRN]

Hospital Course: 
The patient was admitted to our hospital for management of community-acquired pneumonia, pneumothorax, and worsening respiratory distress. The patient had a past medical history significant for hypertension, high cholesterol, and atrial fibrillation. During his hospitalization, the patient was found to have a complex right lower quadrant structure that was later determined to be a right rectus sheath hematoma with extension into the preperitoneal space. The patient was also found to have urinary retention and develop oliguria that later progressed to anuria. 

Treatment:
The patient was treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics for his pneumonia. The patient was also placed on a nasal cannula, switched to enoxaparin for anticoagulation, and received two doses of protamine for anticoagulation reversal. The patient received 1 L of crystalloid and two units of packed red blood cells (PRBC) during resuscitation. Reversal of the patient’s anticoagulation was thromboelastographic (TEG)-guided and included platelets, cryoprecipitate, and prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC). The patient underwent surgical intervention, which involved exploration and evacuation of the hematoma, abdominal packing, and temporary open wound with a wound vacuum. Postoperative critical care was also provided, and ultimately, the patient recovered and was discharged.

Discharge Condition:
At the time of discharge, the patient’s condition had improved significantly and had stabilized. The patient was alert and oriented and stable. The patient was provided with adequate instructions and medications upon discharge. It was recommended that follow-up appointments be made in a timely fashion and that the patient strictly adhere to the medication regimen prescribed by his physicians.

Diagnosis on Admission:
-Community-acquired pneumonia
-Pneumothorax
-Respiratory distress
-Hypertension
-High cholesterol
-Atrial fibrillation

Discharge Diagnoses:
-Right rectus sheath hematoma with extension into the preperitoneal space
-Urinary retention

Discharge Medications:
-None provided

Follow-up Appointments:
It was recommended that the patient make follow-up appointments with his primary care physician and surgical team in a timely fashion. 

This discharge summary is created at the end of the patient's hospitalization and comprehensive in nature.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:

Name: [redacted]

Gender: Male

Age: 22

Admission Date: [redacted]

Discharge Date: [redacted]

Diagnosis:

Oromandibular limb hypogenesis syndrome Type IIB, hypoglossia-hypodactyly

Chief Complaint:

The patient presented with unclear speech and difficulty in tongue movements.

Hospital Course:

During the patient's hospital stay, he was diagnosed with oromandibular limb hypogenesis syndrome Type IIB, hypoglossia-hypodactyly, which is a rare disorder characterized by small tongue and extensive limb deformities. The patient's medical history was insignificant, and his prenatal history revealed that his mother had four episodes of fever during her first trimester. On general examination, the patient had anomalies affecting all the four limbs, and radiographs showed hypoplastic or missing phalanges, metacarpals, tibia, fibula, and malleoli. Color Doppler ultrasonography revealed pulmonary artery dilatation with pulmonary regurgitation.

Intraorally, the patient's tongue was hypoplastic, about two thirds the normal size with a rounded tip, which was attached to the floor of the mouth by a short lingual frenum. The patient complained of altered speech and difficulty in tongue movements, but speech was affected minimally. Root stumps of maxillary left first premolar, mandibular first molars, and mandibular right second molar were present.

Treatment:

Basic oral rehabilitation procedures like extraction of the root stumps and oral prophylaxis were performed. The patient refused to undergo any surgical procedures for the correction of altered speech and tongue movements.

Follow-up:

Due to the rare nature of the patient's disorder, long-term follow-up is recommended to monitor the patient's condition and progress. The patient should be referred to a genetic counselor for further evaluation and management.

Summary:

The patient was diagnosed with oromandibular limb hypogenesis syndrome Type IIB, hypoglossia-hypodactyly, which is a rare disorder characterized by small tongue and extensive limb deformities. The patient complained of altered speech and difficulty in tongue movements, but speech was affected minimally. Basic oral rehabilitation procedures were performed, and long-term follow-up is recommended to monitor the patient's condition. The patient should be referred to a genetic counselor for further evaluation and management.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Diana (pseudonym)
Gender: Female
Age: 25
Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: [Date]

Hospital Course:

Diana, a young woman with a BMI of 16.06 kg/m2, presented with severe alterations in her eating patterns and body image perceptions. She was diagnosed with AN, binge-purge subtype, and matched all DSM-5 criteria for this diagnosis. She reported a history of restrictive diets, weight loss, and obsessive thoughts related to her weight and certain types of food. She also reported body-related image distortions, frequent crying spells, and avoidance of body exposure.

During the rehabilitative protocol, Diana received a multidisciplinary approach tailored to her needs, including endocrinology, psychiatry, psychology, and nutrition. Her blood panels showed no signs of metabolic distress, with values in normal ranges. She received psychological intervention with group psychotherapy and individual sessions focused upon a psyco-corporal therapy approach. Diana also received psychiatric and pharmacological support (citalopram and mirtazapine) to manage her mood alterations. Moreover, the healthcare team provided alimentary education sessions, a nutritional program with fixed meals, and scheduled assessment sessions to ensure adequate monitoring of the progress.

Diana showed a deep insight into her condition. However, her obsessive thoughts connected to her body weight and certain types of food made it challenging for her to follow the assigned rehabilitative diet. Nevertheless, she improved her adherence in the following weeks and reached a BMI of 19.00 kg/m2 at the end of her second cycle of rehabilitative treatment. She was discharged from the Centre and continued her program following only monthly assessments accompanied by individual psychotherapy.

Conclusion:

Diana's rehabilitative protocol resulted in noticeable improvements regarding her eating behaviors and general clinical condition. She was able to follow the changes in her diet both on a quantitative and qualitative level. She showed deep insight into her condition and received necessary support from a multidisciplinary healthcare team, including endocrinology, psychiatry, psychology, and nutrition. The rehabilitative program improved her mood, eating behaviors, and body image perceptions. She was dismissed from the Centre and continued her program following only monthly assessments accompanied by individual psychotherapy.

Reason for Admission:
Occasional mild exacerbations with diarrhea and abdominal pain due to ulcerative colitis

Medical History:
The patient was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis and has been treated with Mesalamine (Pentasa® sachet 2 g prolonged-release granules) twice daily since June 2009.

The patient experienced red-brown urine in the toilet bowl after cleaning with a sodium hypochlorite detergent, and no discolouration was observed when using detergents without sodium chlorite. The patient is discharged with the recommendation to avoid using detergents containing sodium hypochlorite to prevent further episodes of red-brown urine discolouration.

The patient is advised to continue seeing her gastroenterologist regularly.

Discharge Summary

Patient Information:
Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 74
Race: Caucasian
Sex: Male

Medical History:
- Arteriosclerotic heart disease
- Renal failure on peritoneal dialysis
- Multiple cutaneous cancers, including melanoma of right calf and SCC and basal cell carcinoma of scalp, face, and extremities

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted due to a left progressively enlarging pre-auricular cutaneous lesion. The mass was surgically excised and found positive for invasive SCC. The patient underwent radiation therapy, but three months later, the cancer recurred and exhibited rapidly progressive growth. Given the treatment-resistant nature of the SCC, the patient was referred to Head and Neck Surgery for discussion of resection. After multidisciplinary tumor board discussion, the recommendation was for definitive surgical intervention, including total auriculectomy, lateral temporal bone resection, superficial vs total parotidectomy, left modified radical neck dissection, possible craniotomy, and free flap reconstruction. The patient declined radical surgery and elected for a multi-agent nivolumab and cextuximab regimen. After one month of immunotherapy, the SCC had stopped progressing and after three months, the mass had demonstrated remarkable regression. Within six months, the patient was in complete remission, with no evidence of squamous cell carcinoma on his left pre-auricular region or external auditory canal. After eight months of immunotherapy with nivolumab, PET/CT revealed the resolution of the previously seen intense activity mass in the left pre-auricular region extending to the inner ear. After one year of continued treatment with nivolumab, the patient remains free of disease recurrence.

Assessment and Plan:
The patient was successfully treated with a multi-agent nivolumab and cextuximab regimen, resulting in complete remission of the SCC. The patient will continue to be monitored for disease recurrence.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: 1995
Discharge Date: N/A

Chief Complaint:
Malaise, nose bleeds, and sinusitis.

History of Present Illness:
A 26-year-old male presented with malaise, nose bleeds, and sinusitis in 1995. cANCA was elevated, and nasal biopsy findings were consistent with WG, but no other organ involvement was identified. Treatment with intravenous cyclophosphamide, oral prednisolone, and co-trimoxazole were initiated, but his disease remained active. The patient subsequently developed subglottic/right upper lobe bronchus stenosis.

Past Medical History:
Not specified in the provided case report.

Medications:
Not specified in the provided case report.

Allergies:
Not specified in the provided case report.

Social History:
Not specified in the provided case report.

Family History:
Not specified in the provided case report.

Physical Examination:
Not specified in the provided case report.

Diagnostic Testing:
ESR and CRP were elevated at routine follow-up in 2004. MR imaging showed diffusely enlarged pituitary and thickened stalk consistent with inflammatory hypophysitis but no enhancing lesion. Sphenoid sinus imaging also showed extensive involvement with inflammatory tissue and a perforated nasal septum.

Hospital Course:
In view of active sinus and upper airways disease leading to nasal bridge collapse, the patient was treated with humanised monoclonal antilymphocyte antibody alemtuzumab between 1996 and 2002 and received a short course of oral cyclophosphamide in 1999. The patient's subglottic stenosis required steroid infiltration and dilatation and was managed with a small dose of prednisolone.

On routine follow-up visits, the patient reported a "socially disabling" episode of polyuria and polydypsia. MRI imaging suggested progressive sinus inflammation and further pituitary enlargement. The patient was diagnosed with diabetes insipidus secondary to WG and initiated on long term desmopressin which improved his symptoms of diabetes insipidus. The patient also received a further course of pulsed intravenous cyclophosphamide and methylprednisolone in December 2005, followed by two courses of rituximab to control progression of his disease.

Summary:
In summary, a 26-year-old male was admitted with malaise, nose bleeds, and sinusitis, which were found to be consistent with WG. The patient developed subglottic/right upper lobe bronchus stenosis and underwent treatment with intravenous cyclophosphamide, oral prednisolone, and co-trimoxazole. Despite treatment, the patient's disease remained active and was subsequently treated with humanised monoclonal antilymphocyte antibody alemtuzumab and a short course of oral cyclophosphamide. The patient developed a diffusely enlarged pituitary and thickened stalk consistent with inflammatory hypophysitis but no enhancing lesion, resulting in his diagnosis of diabetes insipidus secondary to WG. The patient was managed with desmopressin and received pulsed intravenous cyclophosphamide, methylprednisolone, and rituximab to control progression of his disease.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 63-year-old housewife, presented with knee pain, and a palpable mass on the popliteal fossa. After a failed trial of medications, she was referred to our clinic. The physical examination revealed a soft, non-tender mass in the posteromedial area of the left knee, with overall alignment of the lower extremity being varus by a finger breadth. The patient underwent radiographic and MRI investigations, and an ultrasound-guided needle biopsy was performed. Finally, an open excisional biopsy was performed using a posterior approach, and a moderately solid, yellowish mass was excised.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
The biopsy revealed a benign, well-encapsulated chondromyxoid nodule mixed with fat and bone components arising in the gastrocnemius muscle. Postoperatively, the patient reported improvement of the chronic discomfort, and no calcified density remained on a plain radiograph. The patient was discharged in stable condition with no abnormal neurological or vascular symptoms and advised to follow up as required by the primary physician.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a long-standing knee pain and a palpable mass on her popliteal fossa. An ultrasonography revealed an unusual soft tissue tumor in the popliteal fossa, and further investigation through an MRI showed that the mass was well-defined. An open excisional biopsy was performed using a posterior approach to remove the moderately solid and yellowish mass.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
The biopsy revealed a benign, well-encapsulated chondromyxoid nodule mixed with fat and bone components that was arising in the gastrocnemius muscle. The patient underwent an uneventful postoperative course and reported an improvement in the chronic discomfort experienced. The patient was discharged with no abnormal neurological or vascular symptoms and advised to follow up with the primary physician as required.

Hospital Course:
This 5-year-old male patient presented with repetitive episodes of stumbling and tripping, as well as bilateral ptosis. Initial MRI revealed a diffusely infiltrating pontine mass. Surgical resection was not recommended due to the location and size of the lesion, and he was treated with chemo-radiotherapy and convection-enhanced delivery of antibody. However, an interval MRI one month later was concerning for progressive disease with recurrence of prior symptoms and development of new motor deficits. He was then treated off-trial with panobinostat for six cycles, based on pre-clinical data showing its efficacy in H3K27M-mutated DIPG. However, approximately 13 months after the initial diagnosis, the patient died from progressive disease.

Discharge Summary:
This 5-year-old male patient presented with a pontine mass and was treated with chemo-radiotherapy and antibody delivery. Despite multiple treatments, the patient experienced disease progression and eventually passed away due to progressive disease. The patient's hospital course was marked by a variety of treatments and procedures in an attempt to manage his condition.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Brief Hospital Course:

The patient is a 33-year-old male who was admitted to the emergency department due to severe left upper quadrant abdominal pain. Initial workup revealed a hemoglobin concentration of 6.5 mg/dL and a lactic acid level of 5.7 mg/dL.

Treatment was initiated with crystalloid fluid bolus with appropriate improvement in blood pressure. The physical exam was pertinent for mild abdominal distention and tenderness localized to the left upper quadrant without additional signs of peritonitis. The patient was transfused with packed red blood cells (PRBC) and was found to have perisplenic fluid, an intrasplenic pseudoaneurysm, and active arterial extravasation consistent with a grade IV splenic injury through a computed tomography (CT) scan.

The patient underwent splenectomy due to complications resulting from the injury. In total, he received four units of PRBC, four units of fresh frozen plasma and one unit of platelets peri-operatively. However, he continued to show signs of hemorrhagic shock. The patient was taken to the operating room for repeat exploration on post-operative days two and four due to ongoing tachycardia and decline in hemoglobin.

Further diagnostic workup revealed a variant of Hemophilia A, which contributed to the patient's continued bleeding. He was treated with recombinant Factor VIII to a goal of 80–100%, per hematology recommendations, and underwent definitive closure with hemostasis noted on post-operative day six.

Final Diagnosis:

The final diagnosis for this patient is a ruptured spleen with hemorrhage and a subcapsular nodule with dilated lymphovasculature consistent with splenic lymphangioma. The patient was also found to have a variant of Hemophilia A.

Discharge Medications:

N/A

Discharge Condition:

The patient's condition has improved, and he is stable enough to be discharged at this time.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient is instructed to follow up with Hematology and Surgery in a week for additional evaluation and further management. The patient is also advised to avoid heavy lifting or strenuous activity and to follow a low-fat diet. The patient is advised to report any unusual symptoms or complications.
