Discharge Summary:

Patient: 45-year-old male with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery, and repair of left ventricular (LV) pseudoaneurysm.

Admission: The patient was admitted with dyspnea on exertion and generalized weakness for six months, and TEE revealing the presence of a bilobed pseudoaneurysm of basal inferior and inferolateral wall of LV measuring 5.65 cm × 5.94 cm with a free-floating patch of previous surgery, mild mitral regurgitation, and LV ejection fraction of around 40%. Chest radiograph showed oval bulge on the left heart border.

Management: The patient underwent redo LV pseudoaneurysm repair under general anesthesia with standard monitoring. The surgery involved excision of the pseudoaneurysm cavity, removal of clots, and closure of the inferobasal wall with a dacron patch. The CPB time was around 135 minutes, and the aortic cross-clamp time was 115 minutes. The weaning from the CPB was uneventful with mild inotropic support.

Post-surgery: The patient was shifted to the cardiac surgical ICU with stable hemodynamics, and trachea was extubated after 8 hours of mechanical ventilation. The postoperative period was uneventful with ICU stay of 2 days and hospital stay of 7 days. On discharge, the patient appeared in a stable condition, and he was advised to follow up as per the routine. 

Summary: The patient underwent successful redo LV pseudoaneurysm repair without any significant complications. The patient was discharged in a stable condition and advised for a regular follow-up.

Hospital Course:
Patient 3 is a 35-year-old male who was admitted for further evaluation of a genetic skin condition. The patient was born as a collodion baby and presented with fine white scaling and mild erythema throughout his entire body in infancy. As an adult, the patient only had mild erythema on his face and palmar hyperlinearity. Daily use of topical emollients and moisturizing gels was the only treatment he received.

Diagnostic Assessment:
Next-Generation Sequencing (NGS) analysis of 13 ARCI genes captured in the panel did not reveal any disease-relevant SNV in patient 3. Visual evaluation of read depth and coverage of all the ARCI gene-related exons revealed that exons from 3 to 15 of ALOX12B had no reads in patient 3, whereas they had an average read depth of about 70X in other patients analyzed in the same analytic session. This finding indicated that patient 3 was homozygous for a large deletion removing genomic sequences, including exon 3 to 15 of ALOX12B. This deletion was confirmed by duplex PCR analysis. His consanguineous parents were heterozygous carriers of the deletion, as demonstrated by qPCR.

Treatment:
The patient did not receive any specific treatment during his hospital stay and was only advised to continue using topical emollients and moisturizing gels to manage his mild symptoms.

Follow-Up Care:
The patient was discharged with instructions to follow up with his healthcare provider regularly. He was advised to seek genetic counseling and undergo genetic testing to assess the risk of passing on the deletion to his offspring.

Summary:
Patient 3 is a 35-year-old male with a genetic skin condition characterized by fine white scaling and mild erythema. NGS analysis showed no disease-relevant SNV, and visual analysis revealed a homozygous deletion removing genomic sequences including exon 3 to 15 of ALOX12B. The patient was discharged with advice to continue using topical emollients and moisturizing gels and to seek genetic counseling.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 66 years
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Admission Diagnosis: Exudative and Non-exudative Age-related Macular Degeneration (AMD)

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our tertiary care center for treatment of exudative AMD in his right eye and non-exudative AMD in his left eye. The patient's ocular history prior to being seen by our retina service revealed bilateral pseudophakia followed by subsequent laser capsulotomies for bilateral posterior capsular opacification. He received a total of eighteen injections of ranibizumab and three injections of bevacizumab for the treatment of his eye conditions. 

Previous IOP levels in both eyes were stable until the patient started receiving intravitreal injections, after which he had occasional elevations in IOP up to 20-21 mm Hg in his right eye over the first three years of treatment. After receiving twelve intravitreal injections, the patient began to have fluctuations in right eye IOP ranging from 22-26 mm Hg. Upon examination twelve weeks after the eighteenth injection of ranibizumab, the patient was found to have an IOP of 32 mm Hg on the right side. 

The patient was started on brimonidine three times a day, and upon follow-up examination, his IOP was found to have decreased to 22 mm Hg. The patient was referred to the glaucoma service, and gonioscopic examination demonstrated what appeared to be kerato-precipitates on the trabecular meshwork. Brimonidine was stopped, and the patient was started on prednisolone acetate 1% four times a day. The IOP decreased to 18 mm Hg three days later.

While the anterior chamber was initially devoid of any inflammatory cells, slight cell and flare appeared on subsequent follow-up examinations and then faded with the continued topical steroid therapy. Subsequent workup for uveitis was negative. The IOP remained low over subsequent visits without the use of topical pressure lowering drops, and the kerato-precipitates resolved. The patient has been weaned off of the steroid drops without recurrence of inflammation or IOP spikes, and further use of anti-VEGF agents has been avoided.

Discharge Diagnosis: Exudative and Non-exudative Age-related Macular Degeneration (AMD) with Secondary Ocular Hypertension

Summary:

The patient was admitted for treatment of exudative and non-exudative AMD. He received a total of eighteen injections of ranibizumab and three injections of bevacizumab. Upon follow-up examinations, he was noted to have occasional elevations in IOP in his right eye, and after receiving twelve intravitreal injections, the patient began to have fluctuations in right eye IOP. 

Upon gonioscopic examination, the patient was found to have kerato-precipitates on the trabecular meshwork. The patient received topical pressure lowering drops, followed by topical steroid therapy. Subsequent workup for uveitis was negative, and the patient showed no signs of recurrence of inflammation or IOP spikes. Further use of anti-VEGF agents was avoided. 

The patient is being discharged with the diagnosis of exudative and non-exudative AMD with secondary ocular hypertension.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with complaints of pain in and around the neck since 3 months with a metallic tracheostomy tube in situ. On clinical examination, no scar or ulceration was seen around the stoma. The patient had undergone a suicidal attempt 3 months before, which resulted in severe damage to the recurrent laryngeal nerve. As a result, emergency tracheostomy was performed, and the patient was with a metallic tracheostomy tube for the last 3 months.

Treatment and Procedures:
Upon consultation with the oral and maxillofacial Prosthodontics Department, it was decided to customize tracheal prosthesis for the stoma site. A custom-made tracheal button made of polyethylene urethane sheet was fabricated for the patient to maintain the airway patency of the mature stoma. The urethane tube was inserted into the stoma and customized for stomal patency and fit. Anterior retention was achieved by a 2 mm flange, and lipping was done by heating the posterior region of the shaft and rolled backward by finger manipulation to aid in posterior retention of the prosthesis.

Follow-Up:
The patient recalled the next day for initial follow-up and was instructed about the placement, removal, and homecare of the button. Tubal patency was checked for every 2 weeks, and the initial gradual improvement of speech with reduction in hoarseness of voice was also noted. The intake of food and regular activity were noted and found to be normal. The patient has been on regular follow-up in ENT OPD since 7 months after the placement of this prosthesis, and an excellent cure of his symptoms was noted.

Summary:
The patient was presented with pain in and around the neck since 3 months with a metallic tracheostomy tube in situ. The patient had undergone a suicidal attempt 3 months before that resulted in severe damage to the recurrent laryngeal nerve. Following consultation with the oral and maxillofacial Prosthodontics Department, tracheal prosthesis was customized for the stoma site, and the patient was instructed about the placement, removal, and homecare of the button. The patient has been on regular follow-up in ENT OPD since 7 months after the placement of this prosthesis, and an excellent cure of his symptoms was noted.

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted with symptoms of fever, dry cough, anorexia, and right calf pain. He was diagnosed with benign acute childhood myositis (BACM) caused by influenza type A infection, based on laboratory evaluation and clinical findings. The patient was treated with antipyretics and oral hydration, and no antiviral therapy was given due to late presentation. He returned home to continue supportive care and recovered within a week. Repeat laboratory evaluation was recommended to be repeated within several weeks of presentation.  

Past Medical History: The patient had a history of Kawasaki disease, angioedema, innocent heart murmur, allergic rhinitis, and chronic urticaria. He had an allergy to amoxicillin with accompanying erythema multiforme. 

Physical Examination: On presentation, the patient was alert but ill-appearing and febrile. He had difficulty bearing weight and required help to move. Examination revealed mild throat erythema and bilateral calf tenderness to palpation with increased pain on dorsiflexion. He had full range of motion of all joints and no joint swelling, warmth, or erythema. The remaining portions of his cardiac, respiratory, and abdominal exams were unremarkable. 

Laboratory evaluation: A respiratory virus panel was positive for influenza A subtype H3. Further evaluation revealed elevated creatine phosphokinase (CPK) of 2,102 m/L, leukopenia of 2.60 K/mL, and thrombocytopenia of 166 K/mL. Complete metabolic panel (CMP), c-reactive protein (CRP), erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), and urinalysis were within normal ranges.

Final Diagnosis: Benign acute childhood myositis (BACM) caused by influenza type A infection.

Recommendations: The patient recovered within a week and was discharged home. Repeat lab evaluation was recommended to be repeated within several weeks of presentation.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: Confidential
Gender: Male
Age: 54
Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Overview:

The patient was admitted to [Hospital Name] hospital due to diffuse abdominal pain and distention. A detailed investigation revealed diffuse pancreatic carcinoma with liver metastasis. The patient received conservative treatment and showed significant improvement; however, after discharge, no further outpatient care was received.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission:
The patient presented with diffuse abdominal pain which gradually increased over the past 4 days, radiating throughout the abdomen, paired with nausea but no history of vomiting or jaundice. The patient reported rare alcohol consumption and recent weight loss of 4kg over three months without any significant family history. Examination revealed diffuse abdominal tenderness on palpation with no biliary obstruction symptoms.

Investigations:
Laboratory tests including serum amylase, lipase, and IgG4 were within normal ranges. Elevated levels of tumor markers- CA19-9 and CA242 were observed. Ultrasound revealed a diffusely enlarged accentuated hypoechoic pancreas, which was confirmed by CT and MRI scan images. Additionally, multiple liver hypoechoic or hyperechoic solid masses were discovered.

Diagnosis:
Based on the clinical presentation and investigation reports, the patient was diagnosed with diffuse pancreatic carcinoma with liver metastasis.

Management:
The patient underwent pancreatic FNA under ultrasound guidance confirming suspected carcinoma and ultrasound-guided liver lesion biopsy, which confirmed histopathology of metastasis from carcinoma. Conservative treatment was provided, leading to a significant improvement in symptoms. Chemoradiotherapy and palliative care were offered; however, the patient refused to proceed with treatment.

Discharge Plan:
The patient was discharged after a week of follow-up observation with the recommended follow-up appointment. Contact was lost with the patient after discharge, but after two months, family members reported the patient's health worsening.

Follow-up:
The recommended follow-up appointment was canceled as the patient did not show up.

Summary:
The patient was diagnosed with diffuse pancreatic carcinoma with liver metastasis. Conservative treatment provided significant improvement, but the patient refused to proceed with further treatment. The patient was discharged with a scheduled follow-up appointment, which was canceled as the patient did not show up. No further outpatient care was received, and two months after discharge, the patient's health worsened.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Age: 86
- Gender: Female
- Diagnosis: Lower-extremity predominant quadriparesis, consistent with acute axonal motor neuropathy due to Guillain-Barre Syndrome (GBS)

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a subtle paraparesis that gradually progressed into lower-extremity predominant quadriparesis within one week. Her medical history includes atrial fibrillation, diabetes mellitus type 2, aortic stenosis, and ischemic stroke. Of note, the patient had recently received the second dose of the Moderna SARS-CoV-2 vaccine two days prior to the onset of symptoms. 

Clinical Findings:
Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis demonstrated albuminocytological dissociation (WBC < 1 cells/µL and protein of 129 mg/dL), which is consistent with GBS. The remainder of the patient's CSF immunological studies were negative, including protein electrophoresis, gram stain, glucose, viral PCR panel, and paraneoplastic antibody evaluation. Immunoserologies were negative, including thyroid function tests and anti-ganglioside antibodies. Confirmatory electromyography and nerve conduction studies (NCS) were performed which demonstrated low amplitude right peroneal, tibial, and ulnar motor evoked responses with normal distal latencies, segmental conduction velocities, and sensory responses.

Treatment:
The patient received plasmapheresis for five sessions without notable improvement in her strength.

Follow-Up:
The patient will continue to be monitored for any further neurological deficits or complications. She will be referred to a neurologist for long-term management of her GBS. 

Overall, the patient's clinical presentation and diagnostic work-up are characteristic of GBS with acute axonal motor neuropathy. The etiology of the patient's GBS is unclear, but her recent vaccination may have triggered an immune response leading to the development of GBS. With careful monitoring and proper management, the patient's prognosis for recovery is good.

Discharge Summary

Name: [Patient Name]	Gender: Male	Age: 63 years

Date of Admission: [Admission Date]		Date of Discharge: [Discharge Date]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to left eye pain.

Hospital Course:
Upon examination, the patient had a medical history of diabetes, Fahr's disease, and systemic steroid use. He had been receiving intravitreal injections of ranibizumab in the left eye for macular edema associated with branch retinal vein occlusion. The patient presented with a 1-week duration of left eye pain, and upon examination, his BCVA was 20/200 in the left eye and IOP was 45 mmHg OS. The diagnosis was corneal endotheliitis with anterior uveitis related to an HHV-6 infection.

Treatment:
The patient's treatment included 900 mg of oral valganciclovir twice daily and topical 1% ganciclovir and 0.1% betamethasone four times per day, without discontinuation of systemic steroids. Topical anti-glaucoma agents (1% brinzolamide twice daily and 0.004% travoprost once per day) were also prescribed. Four weeks after the initiation of therapy, the copy number of HHV-6 DNA in the aqueous humor had decreased. Six weeks later, the corneal edema and KPs were completely resolved. Therefore, oral valganciclovir and topical anti-glaucoma agents were discontinued. Topical ganciclovir with topical steroids was continued for eight more months.

Outcome:
The patient's BCVA improved to 20/80, the same level as before the episode of corneal endotheliitis, and IOP decreased without anti-glaucoma agents. At the patient's one-year follow-up examination, lead to endothelial cell density increase.

Diagnosis:
Corneal endotheliitis with anterior uveitis related to an HHV-6 infection.

Follow-up Recommendations:
The patient should continue to follow up with his ophthalmologist as scheduled.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 53-year-old male with massive hand phlegmon and chronic hepatitis C

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our department with a significant hand phlegmon that resulted from a small skin lesion a week before. Although the patient underwent interferon and ribavirin therapy due to chronic hepatitis C, the patient's impaired immune system made him susceptible to infections. The patient underwent a series of debridements with necrectomy and vacuum therapy, which led to sufficient granulation. Subsequently, the patient underwent a radial forearm flap procedure to cover the defect. Although the procedure was successful, the patient's condition worsened due to liver cirrhosis and ascites. Consequently, the patient was given another period of vacuum therapy. The patient was discharged after seven weeks of treatment, with satisfactory wound healing and recovery.

Diagnosis:
Massive hand phlegmon and chronic hepatitis C with liver cirrhosis and ascites.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent several debridements and vacuum therapy to treat the infected areas. The patient was then successfully treated with a radial forearm flap. Still, due to liver cirrhosis with ascites, the patient received additional treatment. The patient was discharged after seven weeks of treatment with good wound healing and recovery of ascites.

Conclusion:
The patient was admitted to our department with a significant hand phlegmon due to impaired immunity, diagnosed with chronic hepatitis C. The patient underwent a series of debridement and vacuum therapy followed by a radial forearm flap procedure. Despite liver cirrhosis and ascites, the patient was discharged with good wound healing and ascites recovery after seven weeks.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admitted Patient: 30-year-old gentleman

Admission Date: [Date]

Discharge Date: [Date]

Diagnosis: Sympathetic Ophthalmia

History and Physical:
The patient presented to the eye casualty service with blurred vision in the left eye five days after an alleged blunt trauma during an assault. The vision in the affected eye was 6/18. There was associated superior sub-conjunctival hemorrhage, extensive iridodialysis, anterior chamber inflammation, and hyphema. Post-treatment, the patient did not attend follow-up reviews. Five weeks later, he presented again to the eye casualty service, this time complaining of blurred vision, pain, and photophobia in the right eye. The vision in the right eye was recorded at 4/60. Fundoscopy showed multiple areas of serous retinal detachments and optic disk swelling. A diagnosis of sympathetic ophthalmia was made, and the patient was admitted to the hospital for treatment.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with pulsed intravenous methylprednisolone 1g daily for three days. The vision in both eyes improved to 6/6 with the steroids, and the inflammation and serous RDs improved. The patient was discharged on 60 mg oral prednisolone and tacrolimus 1 mg BD.

Follow-up:
The patient failed to comply with treatment due to social circumstances, resulting in diminishing visual acuities in both eyes and reactivation of the bilateral granulomatous panuveitis. The patient declined re-admission to the hospital for further review. The length of follow-up was limited to just 2 months post-discharge from the hospital. 

Discharge Plan:
N/A

Discharge Diagnosis:
Sympathetic Ophthalmia

Instructions:
N/A

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [REDACTED] 
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED] 
DOB: [REDACTED] 
Admission Date: [REDACTED] 
Discharge Date: [REDACTED] 

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital for ventricular septal defect (VSD) and atrial septal defect (ASD) closure with patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) ligation. The patient had a preoperative diagnosis of a large subpulmonic VSD, small ostium secundum ASD, large PDA with left to right shunt, mild coarctation of aorta, severe pulmonary arterial hypertension, with L-posed great arteries, and normal biventricular function.

Following induction, right radial artery and right internal jugular vein were cannulated. Intraoperatively, it was discovered that the patient had a rare complex cardiac lesion known as anatomically corrected malposition of great arteries with a large subpulmonic VSD, isthmic narrowing, and a large PDA. The VSD closure was performed with a Dacron patch, and the ASD was closed by direct closure. PDA ligation was done, which also addressed the isthmic narrowing. 

Postoperatively, the patient was weaned from cardiopulmonary bypass, and a postoperative transesophageal echocardiogram showed good biventricular function, with no turbulence, no gradient, and good pulsatile flow in the descending aorta, indicating no coarctation of aorta. However, there was acidosis on blood gas analysis, and the femoral pulses were feeble as compared to radial. 

The patient was immediately taken to the operation theatre with suspicion of iatrogenic COA. Due to abnormal positioning of great vessels, the large PDA appeared to be left pulmonary artery and isthmus as PDA, which was ligated. Repair of the isthmic narrowing was done by resection and end-to-end anastomosis by thoracotomy.

Following the procedure, the patient was closely monitored in the postoperative intensive care unit. The femoral arterial line was placed, which showed good pulsatile trace but the pressures were 40/16 mmHg, and the radial pressures were 70/36 mmHg.

The patient's condition improved, and the femoral arterial line was removed. The patient was discharged in good condition.

Discharge Diagnosis: Anatomically corrected malposition of great arteries with large subpulmonic VSD, isthmic narrowing, and large PDA.

Medications on Discharge: N/A.

Follow-up instructions: The patient is advised to have regular follow-up with the cardiology team to monitor the progress of the cardiac procedure.

Hospital Course:

This 76-year-old woman was admitted to our hospital due to the occurrence of spotty and linear redness in the greater curvature of the gastric body and further examination showed slight congestion, mild inflammatory cell infiltration, parietal cell protrusions (PCPs), and vacuolar degeneration of parietal cells; these findings were indicative of gastroesophageal reflux disease. She received vonoprazan (20 mg) once daily, which appeared to be the cause of the redness observed on the esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD). She tested negative for serum IgG antibody to H. pylori. Her serum gastrin level (SGL) was elevated at 891 pg/mL. 

Treatment and Recovery:

After switching from vonoprazan to esomeprazole, all spotty and linear redness diminished and disappeared, and her subsequent EGD showed no further evidence of redness. Her SGL decreased to 284 pg/mL, and pathology findings have also improved.

Course and Outlook:

Based on current assessment, the patient is anticipated to have an uneventful recovery. The patient has been instructed to return to her physician for further evaluation if her symptoms persist or worsen. Discharge documentation has been provided to the patient.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Patient Name]
Medical Record Number: [Medical Record Number]
Date of Admission: [Date of Admission]
Date of Discharge: [Date of Discharge]
Admitting Diagnosis: Genital Edema and Inguinal Lymphadenopathy
Final Diagnosis: Lymphogranuloma venereum

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital complaining of bilateral scrotal, penile, and suprapubic swelling with intermittent tenderness. The swelling had gradually increased over a four-month period but the patient denied injecting any foreign material into his external genitalia. Past history revealed an episode of penile discharge two years ago that was treated with antibiotics. On examination, the penis and scrotum were swollen and tense, extending to the suprapubic region. There was bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy. Further evaluation revealed multiple non-tender, irregular masses on the penile shaft dorsally without pus discharge per meatus. His white cell count was elevated, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) was increased. Serology test for tuberculosis, fungal, cytomegalovirus, and filariasis from blood and tissue cytology were negative. Computer tomography of abdomen and pelvis showed bilateral scrotal enlargement. An excision of lymph node was performed due to inadequate diagnosis. Lymph node excision biopsy revealed lymphoid follicles of various sizes with prominent germinal centres, and lipo-granulomatous reaction in the sinuses. The patient was treated with a combination of broad-spectrum antibiotics for 8 weeks, including intravenous Ciprofloxacin for 10 days, followed by oral Augmentin for 14 days. Later, Doxycycline and metronidazole were added for another 2 weeks, followed by intravenous Ceftriaxone for a total of 10 days. Following a period of fever, intravenous Meropenem was given for 1 week. Partial resolution of the genitalial and suprapubic swelling with complete resolution of pain was achieved. The bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy had shown partial resolution prior to discharge but later completely resolved on follow up one month later.

Treatment Provided:
- Intravenous Ciprofloxacin 400 mg twice daily for 10 days
- Oral Augmentin (Amoxicillin/Clavulinic Acid) 625 mg twice daily for 14 days
- Doxycycline 100 mg daily plus metronidazole 500 mg three times daily for 2 weeks
- Intravenous Ceftriaxone 1 gm daily for 10 days
- Intravenous Meropenem 1 gm three times daily for 1 week

Recommendations:
The patient is advised to follow up with their primary care physician in 1 month. They should avoid unprotected sexual contact until medically cleared. They should also take measures to prevent sexually transmitted infections by using barrier contraceptives and having safe sexual relationships. Follow a balanced diet and exercise regularly.

Hospital Course:

A 17-year-old male patient with no systemic history presented to the Istanbul University, Faculty of Dentistry, Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery with a large swelling in the left mandibular ramus area, which had developed over the last four years. The swelling was painless, and no orofacial infection signs were reported. On extraoral examination, a hard, subcutaneous, multinodular, painless mass of the complete left mandibular ramus was noted. Deviation of the mandible to the right during mouth-opening and the protrusion were detected. During intraoral examination, there were no signs of pathology at the left mandible or the mandibular ramus area. 

Diagnostic radiological imaging, including panoramic radiographs and Cone Beam Computed Tomography (CBCT), showed that the patient had a lobulated calcified odontogenic tumor developing in his left mandibular ramus area, requiring segmental or block resection. Under general anesthesia, an operation was performed to correct the left mandible, reshaping and removing the lobular part of the lateral and medial side of the ascending ramus. 

The patient also presented with class III skeletal malocclusion, for which orthodontic treatment was administered. Following the orthodontic treatment, wisdom teeth were extracted. Seven years after the osteoma surgery, orthognathic surgery was performed without any complications. Maxilla Le Fort I osteotomy and mandibular bilateral sagittal split osteotomy were performed, and the bone at the left mandibular ramus area was fully regenerated and healthy. One year following the operation, a dental implant was applied to rehabilitate the patient's existing tooth deficiencies.

Discharge Summary:

The patient in this case report, a 17-year-old male with no systemic history, underwent treatment for a large swelling in the left mandibular ramus area. The swelling had developed over the past four years and was painless, with no orofacial infection signs. Diagnostic radiological imaging revealed the presence of a calcified odontogenic tumor, for which segmental or block resection was required. 

The patient was operated on for the left mandible, with no complications, and reshaped with the resection of the lobular part of the lateral and medial side of the ascending ramus. Orthodontic treatment was administered to correct the patient's class III skeletal malocclusion, followed by the extraction of wisdom teeth.

Seven years after the osteoma surgery, orthognathic surgery was performed. Maxilla Le Fort I osteotomy and mandibular bilateral sagittal split osteotomy were performed, and the bone at the left mandibular ramus area was fully regenerated and healthy. One year following the operation, a dental implant was applied to rehabilitate the patient's existing tooth deficiencies.

Electronic Health Record: Discharge Summary

Patient Name: XXXX
Medical Record Number: XXXX
Date of Admission: XXXX
Date of Discharge: XXXX
Date of Dictation: XXXX

Diagnoses:
1. Acute cerebral ischaemia in the middle cerebral artery territory, likely of cardiac embolic origin
2. Coronary heart disease
3. Hypertension
4. Smoking

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Emergency Department with symptoms of global aphasia and right-sided hemiparesis. A cranial CT-scan and extracranial Duplexsonography revealed no intracranial bleeding or significant hemodynamic stenosis of the carotid and vertebral arteries. Thrombolysis with rt-PA was initiated two hours after the onset of symptoms, but the neurological status remained unchanged. Transthoracic echocardiography performed 12 hours after thrombolytic therapy revealed a moderately reduced left ventricular systolic function. Cerebral MRI, twenty-four hours after lysis, revealed a cortical infarct with a clinically asymptomatic haemorrhagic transformation in the left-sided MCA territory. Antithrombotic treatment with subcutaneous low-dose heparin was initiated 24 hours after thrombolysis, and the fluid balance was continually monitored.

Three days after admission, the patient developed acute dyspnea, tachypnea, tachycardia, and an elevated blood pressure. A CT-scan detected bilateral pleural effusion, and TTE revealed an apical thrombus in the left ventricle with reduced ejection fraction. The thrombus was fixed to the hypokinetic anteroseptal wall. Serial TTE performed two days later revealed a complete resolution of the thrombus and hypokinesia, with a left ventricular ejection fraction of 40%. In the mean time the patient recovered from the acute cardiac decompensation. The neurological clinical picture remained stable during the acute phase with a slight improvement of aphasia and hemiparesis within the following 5 weeks.

Discharge Medications:
None

Follow-up:
The patient is recommended to follow up with a neurologist and cardiologist in the outpatient setting. The patient should also continue to manage their vascular risk factors, including hypertension and smoking, and adhere to healthy lifestyle choices. Atrial fibrillation should also be monitored.

Discharge Summary: 

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Admission Diagnosis: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage due to left PCoA aneurysm rupture
Discharge Diagnosis: Postoperative Complete Obliteration of Left PCoA Aneurysmal Sac and Spontaneous Disappearance of Carotid Cavernous Fistula (CCF)

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 67-year-old woman with a history of spontaneous subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) due to a left PCoA aneurysm rupture treated by clip ligation 12 years ago, presented at the emergency department with a sudden severe headache. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain showed evidence of a Fisher grade 3 SAH within the basal cisterns and both Sylvian fissures. After the stent-assisted coil embolization procedure, she had no hemorrhagic complications and her hospital course was uneventful. She remained alert throughout her stay and her follow-up angiograms showed the complete obliteration of the left PCoA aneurysmal sac and the spontaneous disappearance of CCF.

Discharge Condition and instructions:

The patient was discharged in stable condition with a scheduled follow-up appointment with her healthcare provider. She was advised to continue her regular medications and to avoid strenuous activities until her next medical examination. The importance of alarm signs such as a sudden headache, blurring of vision, and seizures were emphasized, and it was recommended to seek immediate medical attention if they occurred.

Follow-up instructions:

The patient is advised to follow up with her healthcare provider in accordance with her recommended schedule for further management of her condition. All concerned were well informed of her care plan.

Discharge medications:

Not applicable as medications were not defined within the given case report.

Signed by: [REDACTED], MD

Hospital Course:

The patient is an 89-year-old Japanese man who was admitted with a history of swelling and pain in the left thigh and a slight fever. The swelling had rapidly increased and become painful within the previous three days. The patient had a one-month history of weight loss but no other systemic symptoms or abnormal clinical findings were reported.

Diagnostic Tests:

MRI scans revealed two soft-tissue tumors in the intramuscular layer between the vastus medialis muscle and the adductor muscle. T1-weighted axial imaging of the distal tumor showed homogeneous low signal intensity, whereas T2-weighted axial imaging showed heterogeneous low and high combined intensities. The proximal tumor located 9cm proximal to the distal tumor had the same intensity on the MRI scan. Laboratory investigation showed an increased white blood cell count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and C-reactive protein concentration. Other biochemical and serologic parameters were normal.

Treatment:

The patient was initially prescribed antibiotics for two weeks, but his symptoms did not improve.
The biopsy sample showed dense infiltration of large, atypical, pleomorphic spindle cells. The atypical cells were positive for CD3, CD30, CD45, and CD45RO but negative for CD20, CD34, and ALK. A CT scan of the thorax revealed mediastinal lymphadenopathy and bilateral pleural effusions, suggestive of extranodal involvement of skeletal muscle. His soluble interleukin-2 receptor levels were extremely high, and chemotherapy was planned. However, the patient died of multiple organ failure five weeks after the first visit to the hospital. 

Prognosis:

The patient's prognosis was poor, and he succumbed to the complications related to his condition.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: R B

Hospital Unit: Facial Paralysis Treatment Unit

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED] 

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Summary:
R B, a 15-year-old girl, was admitted to our unit for evaluation of facial paralysis on the right side. As reported by her mother, the anamnesis was totally negative not describing any important diseases and drugs assumption, and family occurrence of this condition, as well as previous episodes of facial paralysis, were also excluded.

The patient presented with acute pain on the right side of the face, difficulty in biting, dripping saliva from the mouth right corner, and impossibility to obtain a complete closure of the left eye. Further clinical observation revealed a facial asymmetry with edema in the right jaw, difficulty of facial movements on the right side when smiling, and asymmetry of the eyes.

The diagnosis was established as an idiopathic facial paralysis, and according to the House Brackmann scale, it was classified as IV degree (moderate severe dysfunction). 

Treatment for the disease was administered through "self-administered PBM" using B-Cure Laser Pro, Good Energies Ltd., Haifa, Israel, device. Treatment was performed twice a day by cutaneous applications, each 15 minutes, by putting the device in contact with the skin of the right side in the area corresponding to the parotid gland. [REDACTED] 

The patient was observed and treated in our unit and was discharged in a stable condition with instructions on further maintenance care. The instructions were discussed and outlined in detail with the patient and her mother, which they both acknowledged and agreed to follow.

The final diagnosis was idiopathic facial paralysis (IV-degree) managed with self-administered PBM.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 4-week-old male, presented to the emergency department with symptoms of hyporeactivity, feeding difficulties, and failure to thrive. On examination, he was pale, hyporeactive, and had a dystrophic appearance.

After 10 days of hospitalization, the patient developed a low-grade fever and a tender spinal tumefaction in the thoracolumbar region. The whole-body MRI showed the destruction of the T12 vertebral body with the involvement of the disc between T12 and L1.

The laboratory tests showed a high white blood cell count and a positive blood culture for Staphylococcus aureus. An empirical antibiotic therapy with tobramycin, vancomycin, and amphotericin was started.

Diagnosis:

Vertebral body osteomyelitis was suspected and treated as such.

Treatment:

Intravenous vancomycin was continued for a total of 6 weeks.

Outcome:

The patient underwent circumferential vertebral fusion from T11 to L2 due to the worsening kyphosis at the age of 2 years. At present, 9 years after the operation, the patient leads a normal life, and X-ray shows a stable correction with spine sagittal curves within the physiological limits. No neurological deficiencies were detected.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name:-
Age: 68
Gender: Male

Medical History:
The patient had a Grade I subarachnoid hemorrhage(SAH) in 2004 due to a ruptured anterior communicating artery (ACOM) aneurysm. He underwent an initial endovascular coiling followed by a repeated coil embolization in 2008. In 2010, the patient presented with recanalization of the previously treated ACOM aneurysm.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a recurrent ACOM aneurysm, which was treated with further coiling. During the procedure, the coil herniated in the parent vessel. A subsequent injection demonstrated the thrombosis of the left A2 in the anterior cerebral artery without flow distal to the migrated coil.

The SSEP signals were lost from the right leg, and the patient underwent a Merci retriever procedure to retrieve the migrated coil. An exchange maneuver was performed to replace the femoral access with an 8F sheath. An 8F Merci balloon guide catheter was also exchanged to replace the 6 F Envoy catheter and placed in the right ICA with the aim to diminish flow by inflating the balloon at the tip of the Merci guide while retrieving the coil. Tissue plasminogen activator was infused, and an 18 L Merci microcatheter was then advanced proximal to the migrated coil before deploying a V2.0 soft Merci retriever that successfully ensnared the migrated coil. The coil was then brought down to the tip of the guide catheter. At this point, an Alligator 2 mm Retrieval Device was utilized to grab the coil and bring it inside the guide catheter.

Outcome:
Postprocedure angiography demonstrated patency of the left A2. The SSEP signals returned to normal. Postoperatively, the patient remained neurologically intact and was scheduled for a repeated coiling in the future.

Follow-up:
Follow-up appointments are scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and plan the future course of treatment for the recurrent ACOM aneurysm.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Attending Physician: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our clinic for ICL implantation with refraction abnormalities in both eyes. After a thorough examination, calculated ICL models were 11.5 mm and 12.5 mm for the right and left eye, respectively. The implantation was performed by another surgeon, and the patient received the same procedure as described for a similar case with a clear corneal incision. During the removal of viscoelastics, vacuolar changes in the anterior subcapsular space of the crystalline lens were generated in the left eye, similar to what occurred during the same procedure in previous cases.

On the day after surgery, a slit-lamp examination showed bleb-like lesions in the anterior subcapsular space of the crystalline lens, and AS-OCT showed vacuolar change beneath the anterior capsule, in agreement with the previous cases. Nevertheless, UDVA in the left eye was sustained at 20/20 and no issues arose for the follow-up period after 6 months post-operation. No progression of cataract was observed throughout the follow-up period.

Diagnoses:
- Refraction abnormalities
- ICL implantation
- Anterior subcapsular bleb-like lesions

Course of Treatment:
- ICL implantation was performed in both eyes
- Uneventful ICL implantation was performed in the right eye and left eye
- Bleb-like lesions appeared in the anterior subcapsular space of the crystalline lens in the left eye. The patient was monitored over the next six months.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient showed improvement in terms of visual acuity and no adverse effects were reported. No further treatment or medical management was needed at the time of discharge.

Discharge Medications:
[Redacted]

Follow-up:
The patient is recommended for follow-up appointments for monitoring of visual health.

Hospital Course:
The 8-year-old female patient was admitted for presurgical evaluation due to focal drug-resistant epilepsy suspected to localize to the right fronto-temporal cortex. At the time of admission, the patient was experiencing approximately ten seizures per day, characterized by brief periods of unresponsiveness and a blank expression.

Diagnostic Tests:
MRI, PET, and SPECT imaging studies were conducted, which showed subtle asymmetry in temporal cortex sulci, frequent seizures over right fronto-temporal electrodes, and localization to the right temporal cortex. An overnight MEG recording was conducted, which recorded one ictal event. Electrographic changes on MEG and EEG preceded clinical onset by about 6 seconds.

Treatment:
The patient subsequently underwent a tailored right temporal resection from the anterior portion of the temporal neocortex and amygdala to the mid-posterior temporal neocortex. The hippocampus proper was spared. The patient has been seizure-free at 22 months of follow-up.

Histopathological Assessment:
Based on the histopathological assessment of dedicated surgical sub-specimens, Frank FCD type IIa in the MEG-defined SOZ was confirmed.

Discharge:
The patient is being discharged and will receive follow-up care as needed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Length of Stay: 2 days

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery with a history of blunt trauma in the region of the left eye incurred in a fall 1 day earlier. Spiral computed tomography (CT) was performed using 1 mm slices with a soft tissue and bone algorithm, which revealed a non-dislocated orbital floor fracture and a large amount of intraorbital emphysema causing exophthalmos. Due to the clinical findings and severity of the symptoms, surgical decompression was carried out under general anesthesia. Lateral blepharoplasty and transconjunctival incisions were made, and the left orbital floor was exposed, revealing a non-dislocated bone defect. Surgical management with orbital drainage produced excellent results, with sudden resolution of the proptosis and a postoperative improvement in visual acuity.

Diagnosis:
Orbital floor fracture, intraorbital emphysema, exophthalmos, subconjunctival hematoma, loss of visual acuity

Treatment:
Surgical decompression under general anesthesia, lateral blepharoplasty, and transconjunctival incisions were performed. The left orbital floor was exposed, and a non-dislocated bone defect was revealed. Surgical management with orbital drainage was carried out to address the intraorbital emphysema. The patient was put on amoxicillin and clavulanic acid every 8 hours and advised not to blow her nose vigorously and to use a nasal decongestant.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged two days after surgery with restored visual acuity and continuing resolution of the left periorbital swelling and proptosis.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to follow up with the department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery for further evaluation and management.

Signed,
[Redacted]
Attending Physician, Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Date of admission]
Discharge Date: [Date of discharge]

Patient Name: [Patient's name]
Sex: Male		Age: 11 years old

Clinical Summary:
The patient was admitted to our ICU after experiencing a sudden collapse at home. Upon presentation, the patient was in asystolic cardiac arrest, however, cardiocerebral revascularization was established after an extended resuscitation process. Subsequent history revealed that the patient had experienced a similar syncopal attack a year prior. Initial diagnostic brain imaging indicated a diffuse, superficial subarachnoid hemorrhage with cerebral edema, which precluded neurosurgical intervention. The patient was managed conservatively with neuroprotective measures.

Hospital Course:
In the following days, the patient's respiratory function began to deteriorate, leading to an acute respiratory infection in the context of presumed sepsis with ventilator-associated pneumonia. Additionally, cerebral diabetes insipidus was diagnosed due to electrolyte imbalances. Despite escalating treatment with cultures and antibiotic administration, the patient continued to worsen, subsequently developing multiorgan dysfunction, acute renal failure, liver failure, and metabolic acidosis.

Discharge Diagnosis:
The patient ultimately passed away due to cardiac arrest while on ventilator care, the result of extensive subarachnoid hemorrhage. Pathological examination revealed multiple tufts of irregular, dilated vessels in the basilar and interpeduncular cistern area, leading to cerebral edema and brain parenchymal liquefaction. Histopathological analysis revealed the presence of cavernous vascular malformations, suspicious for cerebral cavernous malformations (CCM).

Discharge Plan:
The patient was discharged to the care of a funeral home for ultimate disposition. Family members were notified of the patient's passing, and condolences were offered.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 76 years
Gender: Male

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a metachronous cancer in the sigmoid colon during surveillance colonoscopy after a previous right hemicolectomy for adenocarcinoma of the colon. He had undergone a second laparotomy with revision of the anastomosis due to an anastomotic leak during the immediate postoperative period. During the first postoperative week, the patient developed an enterocutaneous fistula with primary wound failure.

After subsequent management for the non-surgical healing of the fistula for 10 months, the patient underwent an abdominal wall reconstruction with an inlay polypropylene/polyglactin 910 composite mesh that was fixed using polypropylene sutures. The patient remained asymptomatic for 16 months after the primary surgery, after which he was diagnosed with a sigmoid cancer during surveillance colonoscopy.

At surgery, the patient underwent subtotal colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis. Several loops of bowel were tightly adherent to the anterior abdominal wall. After separating the loops from the posterior rectus sheath, an enterotomy was made to extract the heavily deposited mesh from inside the bowel lumen. There were no signs of an abscess, fistula, or sinus formation in the surrounding area.

Post-surgery, the patient had an uneventful recovery and was discharged in a stable condition.

Diagnosis:
- Metachronous sigmoid colon cancer

Treatment:
- Subtotal colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis
- Abdominal wall reconstruction with polypropylene/polyglactin 910 composite mesh

Condition at discharge:
The patient was discharged in a stable condition.

Follow-up plan:
The patient is advised to continue with follow-up colonoscopies as part of his surveillance protocol.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [date]
Discharge Date: [date]

Patient Name: [patient name]       Medical Record Number: [MRN]      Age: 55

Diagnosis:
- Open talus extrusion due to workplace accident

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the emergency department after a workplace accident in which his left ankle was crushed by heavy steel. The patient's left talus was totally extruded through a 12-cm anterolateral wound. An immediate surgical procedure was performed under general anesthesia, which involved urgent debridement of the wound and talus with early administration of preventive antibiotics, tetanus toxoid booster, followed by reimplantation of extruded talus. A transarticular K-wire and monolateral spanning external fixator were applied to maintain the gap of the joint surface in favor of the articular damage repair. The wound was loosely closed.

A second-look surgery was performed three days later to evaluate the healing process. After four weeks, the external fixator was removed, and weight-bearing was prohibited for the initial 3 months. A passive range-of-motion (ROM) exercise and partial weight-bearing was started at POD 3 months. Full weight-bearing and active ROM exercise were initiated from POD 6 months. A MRI scan at POD 6 months showed a substantial signal change between the talus and adjacent bones, which later disappeared on subsequent scans done at 12 months and 5 years.

Outcome:
The patient's ankle joint ROM was 35 degrees of plantar flexion and 15 degrees of dorsiflexion. The patient could walk without aids and could squat, corresponding to an American Orthopaedic Foot and Ankle Society score of 85, comprising a score of 30 points for pain, 45 for function, and 10 for alignment.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged on [date]. No complications had occurred through six years of follow-up, including increased sclerosis of the talar body and joint space narrowing without trivial pain.

Instructions:
The patient is advised to continue following up with the outpatient department for future evaluations and rehabilitation exercises.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 35
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with a complaint of intermittent shortness of breath. The medical history of the patient revealed hypertension. The CT scan of the neck and chest confirmed a mediastinal mass extending from the thoracic outlet to the aortic arch, possibly originating from the left lobe of the thyroid. The patient underwent a combined procedure starting with a left-sided robot-assisted thoracoscopic dissection of the mass followed by trans-cervical enucleation and possible thyroidectomy. The operation was successful, and the patient made an uneventful recovery. The patient was discharged once his chest tube output was low enough to be discontinued.

Diagnostic Assessment:

Computed axial tomography (CT) of the neck and chest confirmed a 6.7 × 6.5 × 3.4 cm posterior mediastinal mass extending from the thoracic outlet, probably the left thyroid lobe, all the way down to the aortic arch with tracheal compression and deviation.

Treatment:

The patient underwent a left-sided robot-assisted thoracoscopic dissection of the mass followed by trans-cervical enucleation and a possible thyroidectomy. The intra-thoracic thyroid blood supply was carefully dissected off the mass with cautery of its feeding branches, and the posterior chest tube was left in place. A left thyroid lobectomy was performed, and the pathological assessment of the mass confirmed multinodular goiter.

Patient Condition on Discharge:

The patient was in good condition at the time of discharge. The patient was advised to take proper rest and avoid strenuous activities for the next week. The patient was advised to follow up with the primary care physician regularly and take the prescribed medications as advised.

Follow-up Plans:

The patient was advised to follow up with the primary care physician regularly and take the prescribed medications as advised.  The patient was advised to report any unusual symptoms such as shortness of breath, fever, chest pain, or difficulty swallowing immediately to the primary care physician. The patient was advised to undergo regular thyroid function tests.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]

Patient Name: [PATIENT NAME]
Hospital Course:

The patient is a 78-year-old male who was admitted with complaints of fever since 10 days and dyspnoea on exertion class III of two days duration. The patient was a known case of squamous cell carcinoma of buccal mucosa, which was excised with cervical lymph node dissection two years ago along with systemic hypertension and renal failure.

On admission, a chest X-ray showed massive pericardial effusion and an electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed low voltage waves, ST elevation, atrial fibrillation, and a fast ventricular rate. The patient developed cardiac tamponade, for which emergency pericardiocentesis was done and 800ml of fluid was drained. Blood and pericardial fluid cultures grew Gram-positive cocci which were identified as MRSA. The MRSA isolate was resistant to multiple classes of antibiotics, including oxacillin, penicillin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, gentamicin, and ciprofloxacin, while susceptible to vancomycin, clindamycin, tertracyline, linezolid, quinupristin/dalfopristin, nitrofurantoin, and rifampicin.

The patient was empirically put on piperacillin/tazobactum, which was switched to vancomycin when cultures identified the isolate as MRSA on the third day. His renal function worsened, and he was put on hemodialysis and mechanical ventilatory support. Subsequently, he developed septic shock and metabolic acidosis and expired on the fourth day of admission due to heart failure.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Cardiac tamponade due to MRSA pericardial effusion

Discharge Instructions:
Due to the patient's demise, no discharge instructions have been given.

Follow-up:
No follow-up required.

Discharge Summary for Patient with CCOC

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 55 years
Sex: Female
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

A 55-year-old female was admitted to the Department of Oral Pathology with a four-month history of painless swelling in the left upper jaw region. The patient was diagnosed with a clear cell odontogenic carcinoma (CCOC) after an incisional biopsy was performed. The tumor exhibited sheets and islands of large clear cells separated by a delicate fibrous connective tissue stroma. The cytoplasm of the clear cells showed diastase sensitive Periodic Acid Schiff-positive granules, indicating intracytoplasmic glycogen deposition. The tumor cells were immunoreactive for cytokeratins (CKs) 8 and 19, while non-reactive for S-100 and vimentin. Focal heterogeneous moderate immunostaining pattern was observed for CK-8. CK-19, on the other hand, showed moderate, diffuse, heterogeneous pattern of immunoreactivity in the tumor islands. Vimentin was strongly positive in the fibrous stromal component only.

The patient underwent radical resection of the tumor with wide surgical margins. The post-operative histopathological diagnosis was consistent with the incisional biopsy results. The patient made an uneventful recovery with no recurrence and metastasis observed 1 year post-operatively.

Summary:

A 55-year-old female with CCOC was admitted to the Department of Oral Pathology with a four-month history of painless swelling in the left upper jaw region. After a biopsy, the patient was diagnosed with CCOC. Treatment involved radical resection of the tumor with wide surgical margins. The post-operative histopathological diagnosis was consistent with the incisional biopsy results, and the patient made a full recovery with no recurrence or metastasis observed 1 year post-operatively.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [Redacted]
DOB: [Redacted]
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Dilated Cardiomyopathy
Principal Diagnosis: Selenium Deficiency

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with a history of chronic diarrhea, fever, and shortness of breath. Following an echocardiography, Dilated Cardiomyopathy was diagnosed, and the patient was prescribed medications to manage heart failure. However, it did not cure the underlying condition. Further investigations revealed that the patient had a deficiency of selenium in his serum. The patient was given oral selenium supplements for six months, which improved his overall condition as he started gaining weight, his symptoms of diarrhea, infections, and cardiomyopathy were alleviated, and his health showed an overall improvement.

Condition on Discharge:
At the time of discharge, the patient's condition improved significantly. The patient had normalised selenium levels, and echocardiography showed normal results after receiving selenium therapy. Follow-up tests showed no further signs of dilated cardiomyopathy.

Plan:
The patient was discharged with a plan to continue the selenium supplement therapy on an outpatient basis. The patient was also advised to follow a healthy diet and to have frequent follow-up appointments with a physician to monitor the improvement of the patient's health.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to our outpatient department with a tuft of hair over the outer aspect of the left upper eyelid. On cutaneous examination, a tuft of 20-25 hairs was observed, surmounted over a noninflammatory skin-colored papular base with a similar morphology to normal eyelashes. The cilia plucked from the ectopic tuft and eyelid were comparable. On ophthalmological examination, normal superior and inferior palpebral conjunctiva ruled out posterior cilia. Visual acuity was 20/20 (OS) and 20/20 (OD) with -0.75 DS in the left eye. 

During the family history elicitation, the parents revealed that the child's late paternal grandfather had similar ectopic lashes over his left lid. On psychical examination, the doctor observed multiple grouped shiny, 1-2 mm-sized, polygonal papules over the midline of the back and left scapular region. On histopathological examination of these lesions, there was the presence of dense lymphohistiocytic subepidermal infiltrate enclosed within the enlarged dermal papilla and interface reaction. The lesions were diagnosed as lichen nitidus on the basis of their characteristic morphology and dermoscopy, which further got confirmed by histopathological examination. 

The patient was diagnosed with ectopic cilia with myopia of the left eye and advised surgical excision. Histopathological analysis of the excised mass showed multiple pilosebaceous hair follicles embedded in a desmoplastic stroma with multiple eccrine sweat glands. The presence of lichen nitidus was an incidental finding. The patient's parents were advised surgical resection of the ectopic cilia, which they refused to.

Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Ectopic cilium 

Treatment Provided:
1. No treatment provided.

Follow-up Instructions:
1. None.

Condition on Discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition and advised follow-up as required.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: [insert patient name and medical record numbers]

Date of Admission: [insert date of admission]
Date of Discharge: [insert date of discharge]

Admitting Diagnosis: Hepatitis

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 27-year-old male with no significant past medical history, was admitted with complaints of fever, chills, and abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting of clear liquids, and jaundice. The patient was initially diagnosed with choledocholithiasis, based on Magnetic Resonant Cholangio Pancreatography that demonstrated cholelithiasis. An abdominal ultrasound also revealed sludge and gallstones in the gallbladder.

Further questioning revealed that the patient was studying to be a physical trainer and was taking a set of supplements prescribed by his local nutrition center, which included Hydroxycut, Black powder, mitotropin, xenadrine, arson, and L-glutamine powder. After admission, a hepatology consult was called, and liver enzyme panel tests showed elevated levels of AST and ALT, total bilirubin, direct bilirubin, and alkaline phosphatase, all correlated with the degree of jaundice seen. Additional tests, including urine toxicology screen, immunological studies for liver, acetaminophen and ceruloplasmin levels, and genetic tests for hemochromatosis, were negative.

A liver biopsy was performed, which showed evidence of acute liver failure and extensive patchy areas of necrosis consistent with acute fulminant hepatitis, with lymphocytic infiltration of the portal tracts and lobular parenchyma.

The patient was asymptomatic during hospitalization and was managed conservatively with discontinuation of Hydroxycut and other supplements. After trending down of liver enzymes, the patient was advised to follow up with Hepatology. On follow-up visit after 2 weeks, the patient had continued improvement in liver enzymes.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient was discharged with instructions to avoid taking any supplements or medications without consulting his physician. The patient was advised to follow-up with Hepatology and continue monitoring liver enzymes. The patient was instructed to return to the emergency department if he developed any symptoms of worsening jaundice, abdominal pain, or nausea and vomiting.

Follow-up: Follow-up with Hepatology to monitor liver enzymes.

Summary:

The patient was admitted with complaints of fever, chills, abdominal pain, and jaundice, which were later diagnosed as acute fulminant hepatitis. The patient was found to be taking a set of supplements prescribed by his local nutrition center, which were discontinued. The patient was asymptomatic during hospitalization and was managed conservatively. After follow-up, the patient had continued improvement in liver enzymes and was advised to continue monitoring and follow-up with Hepatology.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

PATIENT NAME: [REDACTED]
AGE: 55
GENDER: Male
HOSPITAL ADMISSION DATE: April 2020
DISCHARGE DATE: Not Applicable

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY:

The patient, a 55-year-old male with no history of smoking, was admitted to our hospital in April 2020 due to intermittent cough and expectoration for more than 1 month. Chest CT scan showed a high-density mass in the left superior lobe with an enlarged mediastinum and supraclavicular lymph nodes. Percutaneous lymph node biopsy confirmed a diagnosis of lung adenocarcinoma. The patient was classified as having stage IV-B (cT4N3M1c) lung adenocarcinoma.

The patient underwent genetic testing that revealed EGFR exon 21 L858R mutation. Subsequently, the patient started taking dacomitinib (30 mg/d) on May 1, 2020. Three months later, the patient underwent cranial MRI and chest CT scans, which revealed a marked improvement in the lung lesions and pleural effusion. The patient was considered to have a PR. The cranial MRI also showed disappearance of the intracranial metastases, indicating CR. The patient developed mild rash, paronychitis, and oral mucositis during the treatment, but there was no need for dose reduction of dacomitinib. Regular imaging was performed every 2 months.

However, a repeat CT scan on December 30, 2020, indicated progression of lung lesions, recurrence of the left pleural effusion, and an enlarged mass in the left upper lobe. A follow-up MRI indicated progression of head lesions on January 7, 2021. The patient was found to have a T790M mutation by genetic testing and started receiving a new chemotherapeutic drug osimertinib from January 8, 2021 until now.

Overall, the patient had a PFS of 8 months on dacomitinib. The patient's clinical course and management were discussed with the patient and his family. The patient was discharged with adequate outpatient follow-up arranged for the continuation of the appropriate treatment.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
1. Stage IV-B (cT4N3M1c) lung adenocarcinoma with EGFR exon 21 L858R mutation and T790M mutation.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Continue with osimertinib treatment as directed.
2. Avoid smoking and second-hand smoke.
3. Keep all scheduled follow-up appointments with your healthcare provider.

Patient Information:
Name: [redacted]
Date of admission: March 9th, 2018
Date of discharge: [redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a 3-year history of severe low-back pain, accompanied by numbness of the right leg. The patient initially sought relief through analgesic plasters but experienced poor curative effects. As a result of worsening symptoms, the patient presented to our department for treatment.

Assessment and Diagnosis:
The patient underwent a straight leg-raising test, which determined the right side was positive at 70°, and the left side was negative. Based on the Japanese Orthopaedic Association (JOA) and Visual Analog Scale (VAS) scores, the patient was recommended for lumbar magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). MRI revealed multiple signals of the intervertebral disk, bulging of the intervertebral disk at L2/3, L3/4, and L4/5, protrusion of the intervertebral disk at L5/S1, dural sac compression at corresponding levels, LFH at L2/3, L3/4, and L4/5, and LSS.

Treatment:
The patient underwent LF surgery after positioning and labeling the L2/3, L3/4, and L4/5 segments using a CT-guided approach. The needle knife was used to cut the attachment point of the LF to about 2-3 mm depth and pressed for 10 minutes, and the patient was instructed to maintain a supine position for 6 hours. Following the operation, the thickness of the bilateral LF at L2/3, L3/4, and L4/5 was measured.

Outcome:
In the straight leg–elevation test performed immediately after the operation, negative results were obtained on both sides. Follow-up evaluation at 12 months revealed the resolution of the patient’s waist and leg pain. VAS of 0 points and JOA of 29 points were obtained.

Recommendations:
The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-ups with their healthcare provider.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 26-year-old man, was admitted to the urology service for a left testicular swelling. Clinical examination followed by testicular ultrasound confirmed the presence of a tumour, requiring a left inguinal orchidectomy. He then received prophylactic para-aortic nodal irradiation. The patient underwent surveillance for five years, which included routine examination, tumour marker evaluation, and annual CT scans. His beta hCG was measured at 28.5 mIU/mL, which raised concern for recurrence of seminoma. A complete restaging was performed, including CT Thorax/Abdomen/Pelvis and further metastatic work-up, which was normal.

Discharge Summary:

The patient was discharged with a diagnosis of resolved testicular tumour and normal restaging results. He reported self-administration of Nandrolone for one year, which he recently stopped, along with hCG to minimize side effects associated with their withdrawal. He was advised to discontinue hCG injections, and his beta hCG levels subsequently normalized. The patient is doing well with no evidence of disease three years later. Follow-up with urology was recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 14-year-old boy with severe AIS who was admitted to a tertiary outpatient clinical center specializing in conservative treatment of spinal disorders. The patient presented with two primary curves, a right thoracic curve and left lumbar curve, with aesthetic impairment and scores of 51.1 on the TRACE test. The patient was prescribed a rigid brace, but self-reported compliance was only 8 to 10 hours per day. Due to the severity of the curves, surgical treatment was advised; however, the patient refused surgery. A very rigid brace was then prescribed for 23 hours per day, with a thermic sensor applied to verify compliance.

Admission Diagnosis:
Severe AIS with right thoracic and left lumbar curves.

Hospital Course:
During the hospitalization, the patient was monitored with an Actiwatch 2 actigraph to assess rest-activity circadian rhythm disorders and sleep parameters. A low actigraphic sensitivity threshold was selected to accurately measure ten sleep parameters, including Sleep Efficiency, Wake After Sleep Onset, and Fragmentation Index. The data revealed that the subject reached a good sleep quantity, but sleep quality was not excellent.

Discharge Plan:
The patient is discharged in stable condition with a prescription for a very rigid brace to be worn for 23 hours per day. A follow-up appointment is scheduled to reassess the patient's condition and the efficacy of the brace treatment. The patient is advised to continue monitoring sleep parameters and to make appropriate lifestyle adjustments to improve sleep quality. The patient is advised to continue with conservative treatment for AIS, and surgery may be reconsidered if the patient's compliance with the brace treatment improves.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 24-year-old South African-Indian man, presented with complaints of lethargy, weakness, chronic constipation and lower backache, episodes of hematochezia, anorectal pain, and polycythemia. He underwent colonoscopy, which revealed a biopsy from a sessile rectal polyp, but a pathological diagnosis could not be made. He was referred to gastroenterology clinic, where he was initiated on medication for ulcerative colitis but showed no improvement. Blood pressure was found to be high, and treatment was initiated. A repeat colonoscopy revealed rectal prolapse, which resolved with no need for further medication. Investigations for polycythemia excluded primary polycythemia. He received frequent venesections that resulted in lethargy, and they were stopped. After approximately 5 years, he was referred to the nephrology unit, where he was diagnosed with hypodipsia. Magnetic resonance imaging of his brain did not show any intracranial pathology. He was instructed to drink 2 liters of water daily and was clinically well on follow-up 6 weeks later. 

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient, a medical student, initially presented with non-specific gastrointestinal complaints and was diagnosed with polycythemia. He underwent colonoscopy, and a rectal biopsy was taken, but a diagnosis could not be made. He was referred to gastroenterology clinic, where he was started on medication for ulcerative colitis with no improvement. Treatment for high blood pressure was also initiated, but it was later stopped as no left ventricular hypertrophy was found. A repeat colonoscopy revealed rectal prolapse, which was successfully managed without medication. Investigations for polycythemia revealed no primary polycythemia, and venesections were stopped due to frequent lethargy. The patient was then referred to the nephrology unit and diagnosed with hypodipsia. Follow-up imaging of his brain did not show any pathology, and he was instructed to drink 2 liters of water daily, which resulted in a normalized serum sodium concentration. On 6-week follow-up, he was clinically well with no significant change in symptoms.
