Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

The 3-year-old female patient was admitted with thrombocytopenia and generalized petechial exanthema. The patient had been diagnosed with Fanconi anemia (FA) with esophageal atresia type IIIB and had undergone Nissen fundoplication at 17 months of age. The patient had reduced platelet numbers, while peripheral blood counts and erythrocyte indices remained normal. Bone marrow examination did not show bone marrow failure or myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) but revealed a marrow of normal cellularity, mild dysplasia of all three cell lines, and negative PCR results for HHV6, Parvovirus B19, CMV, and EBV. 

The patient received platelet transfusions and intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) infusions, but the thrombocytopenia persisted. Corticosteroid treatment with dexamethasone led to a moderate response, but was terminated due to inacceptable temper changes of the patient. Treatment with danazol, a synthetic androgen, was initiated and led to a satisfactory response with regards to bleeding tendency and platelet count stabilization. The androgen dose was reduced without a change in platelet counts. 

The patient's follow-up bone marrow aspiration and trephine biopsy 1-year after the initial manifestation of thrombocytopenia showed no dynamics as compared to the previous analyses. 

The patient is recommended to continue danazol treatment and follow-up with regular visits to monitor her platelet counts and bone marrow function. Further evaluation may be warranted if there are any changes in the patient's condition.

Signed, [Redacted], MD

Patient Information:
The patient is a 46-year-old male who presented with a six-year history of a plaque lesion on his left hand.

Hospital Course:
The patient was initially treated with itraconazole and terbinafine without improvement. Imiquimod 5% was added as a topical application to the oral medications. However, the lesion initially worsened and became erythematous and verrucous. This lasted for up to four months, after which the lesion gradually decreased in size. Direct mycological examination of the lesion showed atypical filamentous sclerotic bodies, and after six months, there was partial improvement with reductions in the inflammatory process and the number of black dots.

Final Diagnosis:
The patient had a plaque lesion on his left hand with atypical filamentous sclerotic bodies.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient's lesion partially improved with the combined treatment of imiquimod 5% and oral medications. The patient was advised to continue the use of imiquimod 5% and follow-up with the treating physician for further evaluation and management.

Patient Information:
This discharge summary pertains to John Doe, a 57-year-old male who recently received a diagnosis of adult-onset diabetes.

Reason for Admission:
Mr. Doe presented with a 30-pound weight gain over the past decade and recently experienced numbness in his toes. Tests ordered by the physician confirmed a diagnosis of adult-onset diabetes.

Hospital Course:
Following his diagnosis and prescription for metformin, Mr. Doe conducted an independent search for diabetes treatments and found an online ad for Januvia. His curiosity led him to ask his physician about the potential benefits of Januvia, causing him to question if metformin was the best treatment available.

Discharge Plan:
Mr. Doe is advised to continue his current treatment regimen as prescribed by his physician, including taking metformin as directed. He is advised to exercise regularly and make dietary changes to aid in weight loss. Additionally, he is encouraged to discuss any concerns or questions he may have with his physician.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]

Patient Name: [NAME]
Medical Record Number: [NUMBER]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 40-year-old Middle Eastern female with no relevant medical history, presented with progressive blurriness and mild headaches with binocular diplopia. She was diagnosed with bilateral serous macular detachments with cystoid macular edema and trace white blood cells in the anterior vitreous on dilated funduscopic exam. FA studies revealed punctate leakage in the macula and disk leakage OU late in the study. 

Treatment:
The patient was prescribed topical difluprednate, and subsequently improved to 20/40 OD and 20/80 OS with resolution of her headaches by day 7. Given the mild steroid response and elevated IOP, dorzolamide 2%/timolol 0.5% ophthalmic solution was initiated once daily OU. OCT and FA studies showed marked improvement with decreased SRF OS and reduced leakage, respectively. By day 14, the patient recovered to 20/25-1 OD and 20/30 OS with pinhole to 20/25 OS. Difluprednate was tapered to q3h for 1 week, QID for 1 week, TID for 1 week, BID for 2 weeks, and qd thereafter for 2 months. The patient ultimately recovered to 20/20-2 OD and 20/30-2 OS with IOP of 21 OU. Given the mild residual CME OS, the patient continued difluprednate qd OU in addition to bromfenac 0.07% qd OS for 3 months. It was also necessary to increase dorzolamide 2%/timolol 0.5% to BID OU for IOP control. 

Final Assessment:
At the time of discharge, the patient’s lenses remained clear, and vision remained stable at 20/20- OD and 20/25- OS with IOP of 18 OD and 20 OS while continuing management with difluprednate 0.05% qd OU, bromfenac 0.07% qd OS, and dorzolamide 2%/timolol 0.5% BID OU. 

Disposition:
The patient was discharged in stable condition with instructions to continue with her current medication regimen and schedule an ophthalmology follow-up appointment in 3 months. 

Follow-Up Plan:
The patient will have a follow-up appointment with an ophthalmologist in 3 months.

Discharge Summary:
Admitted: [Date]
Discharged: [Date]

Patient: 58-year-old female

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our clinic due to icterus, fatigue, and loss of appetite that persisted for several months. She had a history of acute appendicitis and underwent a surgical operation when she was six years old. She also had a history of hypertension, frequent upper respiratory tract infections, and a previous cholecystectomy. Additionally, the patient was a smoker but did not consume alcohol. During the physical examination, icteric appearance, moderate hepatomegaly, and kyphosis were detected. The initial laboratory results showed elevated AST, ALT, GGT, ALP, bilirubin, and decreased albumin. The chest X-ray revealed dextrocardia, and the thoracic computed tomography showed dextrocardia and scars of previous pulmonary infections. The patient also had chronic sinusitis based on the paranasal sinus CT. The transabdominal ultrasonography showed situs inversus totalis, mild heterogeneous liver parenchyma with grade I hepatosteatosis, choledoc dilatation, and mild splenomegaly. The Doppler ultrasonography of the portal vein revealed mild splenomegaly and dilated portal vein. Furthermore, endoscopic retrograde colangiopancreatography was performed, which showed a dilatation in extrahepatic biliary tracts. The patient was diagnosed with situs inversus totalis with biliary stasis.

Treatment:
The patient was given a 15 mg/kg/day dose of tauroursodeoxycholic acid (TUDCA) to decrease cholestasis parameters. Over the course of nine months, the patient's laboratory parameters turned normal, and there were no abnormal rising in the laboratory parameters.

Outcomes:
The patient's condition improved over time, and all laboratory test results were normal on discharge. The patient was advised to quit smoking and given a referral for follow-up care with a primary care physician.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Situs inversus totalis with biliary stasis.

Condition on Discharge: 
Improved.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: N/A
Age: 41
Gender: Male
Admission Date: December 17, 2015
Discharge Date: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital on December 17, 2015, due to abdominal pain and intermittent fever for 40 days. His medical history includes a 25-year history of aplastic anemia without systematic treatment and a 7-year history of follicular occlusion triad with irregular hormone therapy. Laboratory tests showed white blood cell count of 1.81 × 10^9/L, red blood cell count of 2.39 × 10^12/L, platelet count of 173 × 10^9/L, hemoglobin level of 75 g/L, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate level of 44 mm/h. Colonoscopy revealed multiple irregular ulcers at the end of the ileum, ileocecal, and ascending colon. Based on clinical manifestations and auxiliary examination results, the patient was diagnosed with CD.

During his two-year follow-up period, the patient was readmitted to the hospital due to abdominal pain and diarrhea with fever for 10 days. Prednisone acetate and thalidomide were administered, but one month post-admission, dizziness and fatigue occurred. MDS-U was diagnosed by bone marrow puncture, and an ultra-low-dose decitabine demethylation was performed. The patient responded well to chemotherapy, but his abdominal pain and diarrhea persisted, and he still had recurrent infections, and blood transfusions were continued.

One month later, the patient underwent an allogeneic HSCT. The pretreatment scheme was to improve BU/CY+ATG. Cyclosporine and methotrexate were administered to prevent graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). The patient's abdominal pain and diarrhea symptoms disappeared, and his general condition improved, but he developed hemorrhagic cystitis, cytomegalovirus activation, and invasive pulmonary mycosis. The patient eventually died of severe lung infection 125 days post-transplantation.

Diagnosis:
CD and MDS-U

Treatment:
Methylprednisolone sodium succinate, infliximab, mesalazine, intermittent blood transfusion, and nutritional support were initially administered. Prednisone acetate and thalidomide were also administered during the patient's second hospitalization. An ultra-low-dose decitabine demethylation was performed when MDS-U was diagnosed. The patient later underwent an allogeneic HSCT with a pretreatment scheme was to improve BU/CY+ATG with cyclosporine and methotrexate administered to prevent GVHD.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient passed away due to severe lung infection on day 125 post-transplantation.

Hospital Course:

The patient was treated with bowel rest, intravenous hydration, and intravenous narcotic pain medications for pain control. Isotretinoin was discontinued.

Hospital Course Summary

Patient: 42-year-old female with stage 5D chronic kidney disease related to MYH9-related disease who received a living donor kidney transplant.

Admission: The patient was admitted one month after discontinuation of vGCV prophylaxis with a fever and epigastric pain. Blood tests revealed severe lymphocytopenia, and CMV antigenemia was strongly positive. An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy showed gastritis with a positive CMV PCR. Intravenous GCV treatment was started, resulting in a sustained decrease in CMV antigenemia. After two months of GCV, viral clearance was achieved.

First Relapse: One week after discontinuation of GCV, the patient was readmitted for recurrence of fever and abdominal pain with a relapse of CMV disease. A genotypic testing for ADR revealed two common mutations associated with moderate viral resistance for GCV. Second-line treatment with intravenous FOS was initiated, resulting in a fast decrease in CMV viral load. Unfortunately, six days after the new FOS course, the patient experienced severe acute graft failure associated with FOS nephropathy.

Third and Fourth Relapse: A third relapse of CMV infection occurred one month after the patient's discharge, which was again treated with FOS. Symptom and viral parameter failure led to the introduction of oral BCV, which was administered twice a week for three weeks with good results. However, a fourth relapse was observed, and blood PCR showed a novel mutation associated with moderate GCV and CDV resistance. A two-month course of intravenous FOS was necessary to achieve a complete resolution of CMV infection without any new FOS nephropathy.

Discharge: Currently, the patient's overall condition is normal six months after the final treatment, without secondary CMV prophylaxis. Repeated CMV antigenemia tests have been negative, and the graft function remains stable. Follow-up care is recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not provided
Age: 28
Gender: Female

Admission Date: Not provided
Discharge Date: Not provided

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with severe ulceration of the perineal area, dysuria, soreness of the mouth, fever, non-productive cough, and a facial rash.

Hospital Course:
On examination, the patient had crepitations at the base of her left lung, tenderness on palpation at the right upper quadrant of her abdomen, and an ill-defined rash over her face and neck. The most marked findings were of vulval and perineal erythema and excoriations with discrete ulceration. She developed type 1 respiratory failure with a pO2 of 9.5 KPa on 10 liters of oxygen, and required noninvasive ventilation. Clinically, she began to develop bronchial breathing at her left lung base.

Investigations:
Further investigations revealed that she had a lymphopenia and a high C-reactive protein (CRP) level. Meanwhile, abnormal liver function tests revealed high levels of alanine transaminase (ALT) and alkaline phosphatase (ALP).

Diagnosis:
The differential diagnosis at this stage included human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), herpes simplex virus, and noninfective causes such as Bechet's, systemic lupus erythematosus, and systemic vasculitis. Reiter's syndrome was also considered as it can present without arthritis in women. Tests for various infections and autoimmune disorders were requested.

Treatment:
The patient was initially treated with intravenous acyclovir and high-dose prednisolone. She was later treated with intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics and treatment doses of cotrimoxazole. Her steroids were also changed to high-dose methylprednisolone.

Hospital Course and Discharge:
The patient's symptoms had completely resolved, and she was discharged from the hospital after 10 days of admission. It was later determined that she had an atypical viral infection, with elevated serum titers of IgM and IgG antibodies to measles being subsequently demonstrated, thus confirming a diagnosis of acute measles. The patient was educated on measures to prevent a recurrence of the infection and advised to follow-up with her primary care physician for further care and monitoring.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 43 years
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Admission Diagnosis: Left-Foot Dystonia

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient, a 43-year-old man, was admitted with left-foot dystonia that had been present for the past 3 years. His symptoms had progressed for 2 months before seeking medical help. The patient could not walk normally due to dystonic movement, but he could walk backward, run, and climb stairs without difficulty. He had a history of mildly abnormal walking stance since elementary school. The patient's father was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease since his 70s and he also had REM sleep behavior disorder symptom. The patient's grandmother had parkinsonian features. Extensive neurological examination of the patient revealed inversion of the left ankle with dorsiflexion of the big toe when the patient walked on the ground. Imaging studies including brain MRI and 99mTc-TRODAT-1 SPECT were unremarkable. Laboratory survey results, including ceruloplasmin, blood and urine copper levels, and thyroid, liver, and renal function, were normal.

DIAGNOSIS:
The patient was diagnosed with Segawa disease with GCH1 mutation at exon 6 c.670 A>G(p.Lys224Glu).

TREATMENT:
The patient was administered levodopa with DTI (decarboxylase inhibitor) 100 mg per day, which alleviated his symptoms for only the first 10 days. However, thereafter, even after increasing the dose to 300 mg per day, the patient subjectively felt no response; thus, he stopped medication use. The patient was then treated with botulinum injection over his anterior tibialis, tibialis posterior, and extensor hallucis longus muscles, which considerably improved his dystonia symptoms from Global Dystonia Rating Scale (GDS) 5 to 1. The patient was satisfied with the treatment results.

FOLLOW-UP:
The patient was discharged in stable condition. The patient and his family were advised to continue follow-up with their primary care physician and the neurology team to monitor the progression of the disease. The patient was also urged to continue to adhere to his medication regimen and follow-up treatment recommendations. The patient was educated on his condition and the importance of compliance and follow-up.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
None.

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENTS:
The patient was advised to follow-up with their primary care physician and the neurology team to monitor the progression of the disease.

PROGNOSIS:
The patient's prognosis is guarded, due to Segawa disease with GCH1 mutation at exon 6 c.670 A>G(p.Lys224Glu).

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification:
The patient is a 28-year-old male who was admitted to the department of internal medicine due to symptoms of fatigue, thirst, diarrhea, palpitation, frequency, and a 5 kg weight loss.

Hospital Course:
The patient received an initial diagnosis of type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) at the age of 19 and was treated with intensive insulin therapy. He also had a history of smoking for 10 years, with no family history of any autoimmune or immunological disorders. Neurological examination revealed signs of distal symmetric polyneuropathy.

The patient was diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) due to high blood glucose levels, acetone in urine, and metabolic acidosis, which was exacerbated by Grave's disease (hyperthyroid state). The patient received IV fluid and insulin infusion to control blood glucose, Lugol's iodine, carbimazole, and propranolol to suppress his thyroid hormones. The patient was discharged on insulin medication and thyroid hormones, only to return six months later with mild jaundice and severe anorexia.

Laboratory tests performed revealed elevated levels of liver enzymes and total bilirubin, leading to the diagnosis of autoimmune hepatitis in addition to Grave's disease and T1DM. The patient received prednisolone, Aza, Lugol's iodine, and PTU to suppress the immune system and stabilize liver functions.

Outcome:
The patient's condition improved with treatment, and the dose of prednisolone was gradually reduced over a period of three months. The patient was maintained on Aza, insulin medication, and PTU.

Follow-up:
During the year that followed Aza initiation, the patient reported no side effects, and the thyroid function was controlled with a decrease in thyroid antibodies to almost undetectable levels. The patient is currently being maintained on Aza, insulin medication, and PTU.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with APS III type (A + B), which is the combination of autoimmune hepatitis, Grave's disease, and T1DM.

Recommendations:
The patient should continue to follow up with his healthcare provider and adhere to the prescribed medication regimen.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]

Medical Record Number: [Number]

Date of Admission: [Date]

Date of Discharge: [Date]

Clinical Diagnosis: Regional Odontodysplasia

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 3.5-year-old female, was admitted to the Department of Pediatric Dentistry, Dental School, Islamic Azad University; Tehran, Iran with chief complaints of abscess formation in the left maxillary region, and abnormal crown and enamel on all primary teeth in that region. The patient's mother reported that the abscess had existed for six months and its size was reduced after administration of antibiotics. The patient's prenatal and natal history and the attained medical history revealed no explicit findings.

The intra-oral examination showed excellent oral hygiene and occlusion of the mesial step on both sides. No facial asymmetry was detected, and the lymph nodes were not palpable. However, an abscess on the gingiva above the maxillary left primary molar was observed, which was fluctuant and about 0.5 x o.5 cm2 in size. All the primary teeth on the left quadrant of the maxilla had abnormal crown with yellowish discoloration and hypoplastic enamel. The right maxillary central and lateral incisors along with canine had minor caries. The first primary molar was considerably hypoplastic, presenting an obvious carious lesion. The abscess was related to the maxillary left first primary molar.

The radiological images showed all the teeth in the left maxillary region were present, displayed a typical "ghost-like" appearance in the radiographs. The demarcation line between the enamel and the dentin of the affected teeth was not clear, and the enamel was hypoplastic. All the involved teeth had enlarged pulp chambers and short-slender roots. A periapical radiolucent lesion was detected in the maxillary left primary molar region, which was related to the gingival abscess. The maxillary left first permanent molar appeared to suffer from the same anomaly.

Based on the clinical and radiological findings, a diagnosis of Regional Odontodysplasia was proposed. The patient underwent extraction of the left maxillary primary molar, restoration of the maxillary second molar with stainless steel crown (SS-crown), and a space maintainer (crown, band, and loop) to maintain the space after extraction. A glass-ionomer build-up restoration for the left maxillary incisors and canine was also deliberated. A programmed follow-up visit was planned for maxillary left permanent molar to be built-up by glass ionomer restorations as soon as completion of its eruption.

The laboratory examinations showed that the serum sodium, potassium, calcium, phosphorous, and alkaline phosphatase levels were in the normal range.

Final Diagnosis: Regional Odontodysplasia

Summary: The patient, a 3.5-year-old female, was admitted to the Department of Pediatric Dentistry, Dental School, Islamic Azad University; Tehran, Iran with chief complaints of abscess formation in the left maxillary region and abnormal crown and enamel on all primary teeth in that region. A diagnosis of Regional Odontodysplasia was proposed based on the clinical and radiological findings. The patient underwent necessary extractions and restorations and a follow-up visit was scheduled. The laboratory examinations showed normal serum levels.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 21
Sex: Female
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Hospital: [Redacted]

Reason for Admission:
The patient, a 21-year-old female with a BMI of 10.4, was admitted to the intensive care unit due to severe malnutrition caused by anorexia nervosa.

Hospital Course:
During the hospital stay, the patient's diet was closely monitored and reevaluated. The patient was provided with a nutrition plan that included a balanced diet with proper macro and micronutrient intake. The patient's treatment also involved counseling sessions with a nutritionist to educate her on the importance of a healthy diet and the negative consequences of continued malnutrition. The patient was cooperative throughout her stay at the hospital.

Investigations:
A stool sample was collected aseptically from the patient and stored at -80°C for analysis. DNA extracted from the stool sample was used to identify eukaryotic organisms present in the patient's gut. PCR amplification using multiple primer pairs enabled the identification of 28 eukaryotic species consisting of fungi, protozoa, helminthes, arthropods, and plants. Further investigations of the colony samples revealed the growth of six fungal species, namely A. ruber, A. flavus, C. capitatum, M. globosa, M. restricta, and M. pachydermatis.

Treatment:
The patient's treatment involved close monitoring of the patient's condition, including daily weight measurements, nutrition counseling sessions, and regular psychological therapy sessions. Additionally, a course of vitamins and minerals was prescribed to correct any nutrient deficiencies resulting from malnutrition. The patient's treatment was adjusted based on her progress and the results of investigations.

Discharge Plan:

The patient was advised to maintain a healthy and balanced diet and to stay active. The patient was also instructed to report any symptoms or concerns regarding her health immediately.

Follow-up appointments were scheduled for the patient with a nutritionist and psychologist. The patient was also advised to keep a record of her daily nutrient intake and to continue monitoring her weight regularly.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Date of Admission]
Discharge Date: [Date of Discharge]
Length of Stay: [Number of Days Spent in Hospital]

Patient Name: [Patient Name]
Gender: Male
Age: 46 years old
Medical Record Number: [Patient MRN]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to chest pain.

History and Examination Findings:
The patient has a history of TOF diagnosed since childhood, but was able to get married and have two healthy children. Upon examination, minimal cyanosis was observed, along with clubbing on the extremities and a systolic murmur along the left sternal border. The electrocardiogram revealed ST elevation in leads II, III, aVF with incomplete right bundle branch block, a right axis deviation and right ventricular hypertrophy. Transthoracic echocardiography showed typical signs of TOF. A significant increase was noted in the patient's cardiac troponin T levels, with levels reaching 2,999 ng/mL.

Hospital Course:
The patient was diagnosed with STEMI and received standard medications, including aspirin, clopidogrel, rosuvastatin, nitroglycerin, and enoxaparin. Emergency coronary angiography showed total occlusion of a large right coronary artery (RCA) from the second segment. Thrombus aspiration with catheter was performed multiple times and significant thrombus was sucked from RCA. However, after thrombus aspiration, there was still significant thrombus in the second and third segment of RCA, with thrombolysis in myocardial infarction (TIMI) flow grade 2 on coronary angiogram. Due to the absence of obvious lesions and the fact that the diameter of RCA was 7.0 mm by quantitative coronary analysis, stenting or ballooning was deemed unreasonable. Therefore, intracoronary thrombolytic therapy with 25 mg of alteplase directly through the guiding catheter for 5 min was performed. Follow-up coronary angiography revealed complete dissolution of thrombus with TIMI 3 flow.

Post-Procedure Progress and Findings:
After the procedure, the complete blood count showed erythrocytosis with erythrocytes of 5.93 × 1012 /L, hemoglobin of 202 g/L, and hematocrit of 0.58, along with normal white blood cells and platelets. Blood pressure was 90/60 mm Hg without inotrope or vasopressor. The patient received saline infusion with a total volume of 2,000 mL for 3 days. The follow-up hematocrit was reduced to 0.45 and blood pressure increased to 120/80 mm Hg. Holter ECG after the procedure revealed sinus tachycardia without atrial fibrillation, flutter or atrioventricular block. Cardiac computed tomography (CT) showed typical TOF with 10 mm ventricular septal defect (VSD) and severe supravalvular pulmonary stenosis.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in stable condition 10 days after the procedure with standard medications for STEMI.

Follow-up:
Follow-up appointments have been scheduled for the patient to monitor their condition and adjust their medication as needed.

Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow their treatment plan and attend all scheduled follow-up appointments. Any changes in their condition should be reported to their healthcare provider immediately.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not Available
DOB: Not Available
Sex: Male
Hospital Admission Dates: Not Available

History of Presenting Illness:
The patient was diagnosed with AIDS with clinical symptoms consisting of fever, oral thrush, diarrhea, weight loss, and anorexia. The CD4+ T-lymphocyte cell count was 203 cells/mm3, and an HIV viral load was not available.

Hospital Course:
The patient was started on ART with a medication regimen consisting of zidovudine, lamivudine, and indinavir, as well as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, in early 2002. However, the patient was unable to tolerate indinavir and was switched to efavirenz, not knowing he was HIV-2 positive. The patient had clinical improvement with the resolution of presenting symptoms; however, the CD4+ cell count remained low, and the HIV viral load was undetectable.

In 2005, the patient's CD4+ cell count dropped to 92 cells/mm3, and the ART was changed to zidovudine, didanosine, and lopinavir/ritonavir. The patient continued to have recurrent oral thrush with significant weight loss. The patient's HIV viral load remained undetectable throughout despite a steadily decreasing CD4+ cell count. The patient died at home in 2005.

Summary:
The patient was diagnosed with AIDS, with the initial finding of a low CD4+ cell count. The patient was started on ART, and despite the switch in medication, the patient had clinical improvement with the resolution of presenting symptoms, and the HIV viral load remained undetectable. However, the CD4+ cell count steadily decreased, and the patient had recurrent oral thrush with significant weight loss. Unfortunately, the patient passed away at home in 2005.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED], Age: 2-year-old, Male
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Final Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with a renal artery aneurysm and an arteriovenous malformation, which required a left nephrectomy. Histological examination revealed a tumor consisting of a proliferation of spindle cells with myxoid changes of medial smooth muscle, characterizing angiodysplasia, and was diagnosed as a myofibroblastic stromal tumor (MST).

Hospital Course:
The patient was referred to the pediatric surgery department with a prenatal diagnosis of a malformation uropathy. An ultrasonography and color Doppler showed a vascular mass of the left renal helium, measuring 25 mm × 21 mm, with a vascular flow in the renal artery which pushed down the renal vein. An angiography of the renal arteries revealed a true preostial aneurysm measuring 7mm × 12mm. On renal scintigraphy, the left kidney had an altered function (glomerular renal function at 29%) with normal drain, and the right kidney showed a good capture function (glomerular renal function at 71%). An attempted endovascular treatment failed, and no vascular bypass gesture was performed, leading to a left nephrectomy. The patient was monitored and showed no signs of local recurrence during the follow-up period of 4 months.

Summary:
The patient was diagnosed with a renal artery aneurysm and an arteriovenous malformation, which could not be treated with endovascular treatment, leading to a left nephrectomy. Histological examination showed an unencapsulated tumor consisting of a proliferation of spindle cells with myxoid changes of medial smooth muscle, characterizing angiodysplasia and was diagnosed as MST. The patient showed no signs of local recurrence during the follow-up period, indicating positive recovery.

Discharge Summary
Patient Name: [redacted]

Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis:
Seizure disorder

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted on [redacted] with symptoms of stiffness in the lower and upper extremities since birth. Upon admission, the patient presented with head tilting backwards, staring, apnea, and hypertonia in upper and lower limbs. The neonate was intubated and ventilated immediately.

Blood, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), urine and stool testing results were unremarkable. No growth was reported in blood and CSF culture. Cardiac enzyme profiling, electrolyte analyses, blood amino acid and acylcarnitine spectrum analyses for inherited metabolic diseases, and comprehensive panel of urine organic acids were unrevealing. Thyroid, liver and renal functions were normal. Cytomegalovirus and herpes virus, and their respective antibodies were negative as determined by PCR and ELISA, respectively. Chest radiography, electrocardiography, echocardiography and head MRI did not identify abnormalities. The automated auditory brainstem response was normal. Video electroencephalogram (EEG) was recorded and showed intermittent or continuous discharges (hypsarrhythmia) of generalized or multi-focal spike-waves and spike-and-slow waves, in line with epileptic encephalopathy.

The neonate was treated with Phenobarbital, diazepam, vitamin B6, levetiracetam, and clonazepam over the course of admission.

Discharge Condition:
Stable

Discharge Medications:
Levetiracetam and clonazepam

Follow-up:
The patient is to follow-up with their primary care physician.

Summary:
This was a 12-day-old neonate presenting with seizure disorder and stiffness in the lower and upper extremities since birth. The neonate was intubated and ventilated immediately. Blood, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), urine and stool testing results were unremarkable. The neonate was treated with Phenobarbital, diazepam, vitamin B6, levetiracetam, and clonazepam over the course of admission. The patient is to follow-up with their primary care physician.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

Patient Information:
Name: [insert name]
Age: 56 years
Gender: Female
Medical History: Chronic Hepatitis B

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital for evaluation of a 4 cm-sized SMT in the gastric fundus. She had been experiencing epigastric discomfort and dyspepsia for the past year, but had not experienced weight loss. She was diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B 18 years ago, but had not been receiving regular check-ups.

Upon admission, the patient's vital signs were stable and physical examination did not show any abnormalities. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy revealed a 4 cm-sized mass in the gastric fundus, which showed normal gastric mucosa and did not change shape when pushed with forceps. Dynamic abdominal CT scan showed two masses, one 3 cm-sized mass in the right posterior superior portion of the liver, and another 4.5 cm-sized pedunculated mass originating from the left lateral segment of the liver. Blood tests and tumor markers were within normal ranges, except for elevated serum HBV-DNA level.

The patient underwent laparoscopic resection due to the long peduncle of the left lobe mass and its atypical CT findings, which made it difficult to differentiate from malignant tumor. During surgery, a 4.5×2.5×1.2 cm-sized mass with a long peduncle was observed. The surface was smooth and dark red, and the cut section showed spongy-shaped cystic lesions beneath the capsule. Microscopic examination revealed various sized, large vascular channels lined with single-layered flattened endothelial cells, separated and supported by fibrous septa. After the operation, the patient was discharged without complications and currently under regular follow-up for chronic hepatitis B. 

Summary:
The patient was admitted for evaluation of a 4 cm-sized SMT in the gastric fundus with a medical history of chronic hepatitis B. Upon admission, there were no physical abnormalities except for the presence of the SMT. Laboratory examinations and imaging showed the presence of two masses in the liver, including a 4.5 cm-sized pedunculated mass originating from the left lateral segment. Laparoscopic resection was performed due to the atypical findings of the left lobe mass, which was considered difficult to differentiate from malignant tumor, and the possibility of rupture. The patient was discharged without complications and currently under regular follow-up for chronic hepatitis B.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Length of Stay: [REDACTED]

Diagnosis:
- Acute lymphocytic myocarditis
- Giant cell myocarditis

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital due to cardiogenic shock. After being supported by an Impella-2.5L, the patient was placed on a Heartmate-II. Histology of the LV-apical core section during this admission showed multifocal interstitial inflammatory infiltrates with edema and extensive myocytes destruction, without giant cell or extensive necrosis. Immunofluorescence was suggestive of acute lymphocytic myocarditis. After receiving a defibrillator, the patient was discharged on standard heart failure therapy. During an at-home follow-up, the patient experienced two weeks of congestive symptoms and was admitted again.

An endomyocardial biopsy (EBM) during this admission revealed severe mycocytes' dropout associated primarily with granulation tissue, a mixed inflammatory infiltrate, and the presence of multinucleated giant cell with a non-myogenic appearance, all suggestive of giant cell myocarditis. The patient was administered the immunosuppressive therapy of high dose corticosteroids and cyclosporine. Unfortunately, the patient developed incessant ventricular tachycardia and profound right ventricular failure, requiring amiodarone and milrinone. An urgent transplantation was carried out 16 days later.

Histopathology of the explanted heart showed diffuse and irregular interstitial fibrosis without extensive necrosis, associated with residual areas of granulation tissue, mild to moderate lymphocytic infiltrates, and mild foci of myocytes' damage. The immunosuppressive regimen comprised of rabbit antithymocyte globulin (RATG) induction, corticosteroids, mofetilmycophenolate, basiliximab, and later tacrolimus. Unfortunately, the patient died of multi-organ failure one month after transplantation.

Follow-Up Plan:
None.

Follow-Up Recommendations:
None.

Instructions:
None.

Hospital Course:

Admission: A 32-year-old female with a one-month history of fever and elevated levels of noradrenaline presented with headaches and general malaise. Laboratory findings indicated an inflammatory state, anemia, coagulopathy, and malnutrition. Further examinations led to the diagnosis of an IL-6-producing pheochromocytoma. The patient was then scheduled for left adrenal tumor resection.

Treatment: The patient was prescribed oral loxoprofen for systemic inflammation and oral doxazosin for pheochromocytoma. The surgery was initially scheduled after two months of preoperative treatment, but was preponed due to persistently high inflammatory markers, anemia, malnutrition, and coagulopathy. The dosage of doxazosin peaked at 12 mg. Anemia was managed with packed red blood cells daily. 

Surgery: The patient was administered general anesthesia and an erector spinae plane block for perioperative analgesia. Epidural anesthesia was not administered due to coagulopathy. An arterial catheter was placed in the radial artery, and BP management was achieved with phentolamine and remifentanil infusion. Fluctuations in BP occurred during direct tumor manipulation, and required bolus infusion of phentolamine. The surgery was completed with a continuous infusion of noradrenaline.

Outcome: The patient's postoperative chest radiography was normal, and laboratory results showed improved inflammatory markers. The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit and eventually moved to the general ward on POD1. The patient was discharged on POD8 with no eventful postoperative complications.

Hospital Course:
A 56-year-old Chinese male presented to the ophthalmic clinic with a chief complaint of blurry vision and redness in both eyes. A month later, he was diagnosed with bilateral uveitis and started on methylprednisolone treatment. However, his visual acuity rapidly deteriorated and he developed fever with an evening peak and night sweats. Subcutaneous nodules with skin ulceration were observed on the trunk and upper extremities. Diagnostic vitrectomy of the left eye was performed, and pathological examination revealed infiltration of atypical lymphoid cells. Further biopsies confirmed a diagnosis of Extranodal NK/T-cell lymphoma (ENKTL) with skin involvement and positive Epstein-Barr virus-encoded RNA in situ hybridization. A subsequent PET-CT scan demonstrated significant uptake of 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose in the skin, nasopharynx, small intestine, and kidneys, leading to a diagnosis of stage IV ENKTL.

Treatment:
The patient was initially treated with six cycles of SMILE chemotherapy regimen and demonstrated complete remission after four cycles. However, while autologous stem-cell transplantation was being planned as consolidation therapy, the patient developed drowsiness and dyspnea with acute onset and rapid progression and was diagnosed with CNS relapse with leptomeningeal involvement. Salvage treatment with two cycles of anti-programmed cell death 1 antibody (sintilimab) combined with P-GEMOX regimen (gemcitabine, oxaliplatin, and pegaspargase) and five cycles of intrathecal injection (10 mg methotrexate, 50 mg cytarabine, and 5 mg dexamethasone) were administered twice a week. The patient's clinical status gradually improved, and dyspnea was relieved.

Discharge Summary:
The patient's clinical course was complicated by a diagnosis of ENKTL with CNS relapse. Salvage treatment was administered for a suspected CNS relapse and achieved clinical improvement. However, the patient eventually developed pancytopenia and passed away 12 months after the initial diagnosis.

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY:

This is a summary of hospital course for a 28-year-old male patient with a soft reddish mass on his left scrotum. The patient sought medical attention for the mass which had been gradually growing for the past one year. The surface of the mass was observed to be irregular. No pain or discomfort was associated with the mass.

Upon physical examination at the hospital, no noticeable enlargement of superficial lymph nodes was observed in the bilateral parts of the groin. A biopsy was conducted on the mass which revealed a well-circumscribed nodule composed of small, monomorphous cuboidal poroid cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm and monomorphic nuclei. The histopathologic examination led to the diagnosis of eccrine poroma.

The patient underwent treatment for the eccrine poroma while hospitalized to rid his left scrotum of the mass. He was monitored closely and responded well to the treatment.

The hospital course of the patient was uneventful. On the day of discharge, the patient was stable and in good health. The patient was discharged in stable condition with clear instructions for follow-up appointments and care.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted on <redacted> for bariatric surgery due to significant impairment of quality of life and failure of intensive lifestyle modification to maintain weight loss for 1 year. The patient's past medical history was notable for hypothyroidism and fatty liver disease. The patient did not have any other medical conditions, except for one full-term pregnancy ended by an uncomplicated elective cesarean section 7 years ago and one first-trimester spontaneous abortion 6 months ago.

After reviewing the patient's medical history and conducting necessary assessments, the patient underwent successful laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy without any complications and was discharged from the hospital on postoperative day two.

The patient received proper monitoring throughout her pregnancy by a multidisciplinary team, which included high-risk obstetrics, bariatric surgeons, and nutritionists. She was also prescribed prenatal vitamins and one Calcicare tablet daily. Her pregnancy continued uneventfully, and she underwent an elective cesarean section at 39-weeks to deliver a healthy full-term girl. The infant reached all expected milestones during the first 6 months of her life, and the mother achieved significant weight loss post-surgery.

Recommendations:

The patient was advised to continue with the recommended postoperative diet and exercise plans. She was also recommended to schedule regular follow-up visits with her primary care physician, endocrinologist, and bariatric surgeon to monitor her postoperative health and potential complications.

Overall, the patient had a successful bariatric surgery and a healthy pregnancy outcome.

Discharge Summary:

Gender: Male

History and Reason for Hospitalization:

The patient presented with the complaint of unsatisfactory facial appearance due to prominent upper front teeth and backwardly placed lower front teeth. On clinical examination, he had a convex profile with retrognathia. Cephalometrically, there was a mandibular corpus deficiency of approximately 8 mm in the sagittal plane. It was diagnosed as a case of mandibular body deficiency, which was planned to be addressed by mandibular advancement by bilateral sagittal split osteotomy.

Hospital Course:
Bilateral sagittal split ramus osteotomy (BSSRO) was performed, and the mandible was advanced by approximately 8 mm. The patient received postoperative antibiotics and pain killers for five days. The patient was discharged on the 8th postoperative day. Orthodontic treatment was started after 2 weeks.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient is stable and has completed the prescribed treatment plan for the mandibular advancement. The patient has scheduled follow-up appointments for further orthodontic treatment.

Instructions and Follow-Up:

The patient is advised to continue taking the prescribed medications and complete the orthodontic treatment. The patient has scheduled follow-up appointments with the orthodontist for further management. The patient should contact the medical team if any complications or concerns arise.

Important Information:

The patient underwent bilateral sagittal split osteotomy for correction of mandibular body deficiency. The patient received postoperative antibiotics and pain killers. The completed treatment plan included orthodontic treatment, which was started after 2 weeks of surgery. Follow-up appointments were scheduled for further management.

HOSPITAL COURSE:

This discharge summary outlines the hospital course of a 58-year-old female patient who presented to our institute with progressively decreased vision in the right eye. She was found to have a white intumescent cataract in the right eye and nuclear, cortical, and posterior subcapsular cataract in the left eye. The patient underwent femtosecond laser-assisted cataract surgery (FLACS) targeting plano in both eyes using the LenSx laser platform. While performing the FLACS on the right eye, a plume of cortex was noted to rise into the anterior chamber. Although the capsulotomy was initially incomplete, capsulotomy forceps were utilized to redirect the radial extension, and the remainder of the cataract surgery was uneventful. The patient's uncorrected distance visual acuity was 20/400, 20/20-2, and 20/25+ on day one, week 1, and week 2, respectively. 

SUMMARY:

The patient was admitted to our institute with a complaint of progressively decreased vision in the right eye. During her hospital course, she underwent FLACS for the treatment of her cataracts. While performing the procedure on her right eye, a plume of cortex was noted to rise into the anterior chamber, and the initial capsulotomy was incomplete with attachments at 6:00 and 11:00, and radial extensions at 4:00 and 11:00. Capsulotomy forceps were utilized to free the capsulotomy edges and redirect the radial extension, and the remainder of the cataract surgery was uneventful. The patient was discharged with an uncorrected distance visual acuity of 20/25+ on week two.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:

- White intumescent cataract in the right eye
- Nuclear, cortical, and posterior subcapsular cataract in the left eye

PROCEDURES:

- Femtosecond laser-assisted cataract surgery targeting plano in both eyes using the LenSx laser platform

HOSPITAL COURSE:

- Admission for the treatment of cataracts
- FLACS performed on both eyes
- During the FLACS on the right eye, a plume of cortex was noted to rise into the anterior chamber, and the initial capsulotomy was incomplete with attachments at 6:00 and 11:00, and radial extensions at 4:00 and 11:00
- Capsulotomy forceps were utilized to free the capsulotomy edges and redirect the radial extension
- The remainder of the cataract surgery was uneventful
- Discharged with an uncorrected distance visual acuity of 20/25+ on week two.

Discharge Summary for a 36-Yr-Old Female with Left Ocular Pain, Headache, Diplopia, and Tinnitus

Chief Complaint: Left ocular pain, headache, diplopia, and tinnitus.

History of Present Illness: The patient presented to our facility with a complaint of left ocular pain, headache, diplopia, and tinnitus, which started one month prior to presentation. Physical examination showed a bruise at a trauma site on her skin and chronic dislocation of the first metatarsal joint on her foot. Hypermobility of the distal interphalangeal joints of the hands was observed, along with a kyphosis of the lumbar and thoracic vertebrae. Magnetic resonance imaging identified a large CCF, which was successfully treated with detachable balloons. During the procedure, a pseudoaneurysm of the left proximal internal carotid artery occurred and was treated with a stent. A large subcutaneous hematoma occurred at the puncture site after angiography. Surgical evacuation of a massive hematoma was performed, followed by the insertion of a stent graft into the punctured femoral artery, with arteriotomy to control bleeding.

Past Medical History: No significant past medical history.

Social History: The patient denies any tobacco, alcohol, or drug use.

Family History: The patient has a family history of chronic subluxation of the proximal interphalangial joint of the left hand in her daughter.

Immunization Status: Up to date.

Allergies:
None documented.

Hospital Course: The patient underwent treatment for her CCF, which was successfully resolved. She experienced postoperative ophthalmoplegia and loss of visual acuity due to a neurotropic corneal ulcer. These symptoms were managed appropriately, and the patient was discharged from our facility in stable condition.

Laboratory and Diagnostic Data: Magnetic resonance imaging revealed a large CCF, which was confirmed by angiography. Mutation analysis by DNA sequencing of the COL3A1 gene revealed a duplication of 15 base pairs, which resulted in an interposition of five amino acids and a subsequent formation of a repeat unit composed of only two amino acids.

Follow-up Care: The patient was instructed to follow up with her primary care physician for continued monitoring and management of her condition.

Discharge Medications:
None documented.

Discharge Condition: The patient was discharged from our facility in stable condition.

Discharge Diagnoses: CCF.

Discharge Summary:

Patient is a 67-year-old female with a history of Type 2 diabetes, high blood pressure, systemic sclerosis and Sjögren syndrome who presented with lymphadenopathy that was diagnosed as Epstein-Barr virus-positive diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. She was treated with rituximab, vincristine, doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide and prednisolone (R-CHOP), prophylactic allopurinol (300 mg for 10 days) and venetoclax (800 mg/day orally). One day after chemotherapy, she received pegfilgrastim (6 mg). On Day 6, she developed febrile neutropenia due to pneumonia. On Day 7, she was found to have hypokalaemia, hypocalcaemia, hypophosphataemia, new-onset proteinuria, elevated β2-microglobulin excretion and high sodium chloride excretion. Electrocardiogram showed premature atrial contractions, flattened T-waves and a U-wave configuration in V1.
 
Venetoclax was discontinued prematurely on Day 7 and intravenous infusion of potassium, phosphate, magnesium and calcium was started. Electrolytes remained normal after discontinuation of i.v. supplementation. The patient had no symptoms during her stay in the hospital and was discharged in a stable condition. 
 
In summary, the patient's electrolyte abnormalities were characterized by hypokalaemia, hypocalcaemia, and hypophosphataemia with proteinuria and high sodium chloride excretion. Electrocardiogram showed premature atrial contractions, flattened T-waves and a U-wave configuration in V1. Venetoclax was identified as the possible offending agent and was discontinued early in the treatment course. The patient was discharged in a stable condition.

Hospital Course:
A 5-month-old girl was admitted to this center due to worsening respiratory distress. She was initially diagnosed with pneumonia and treated with intravenous piperacillin-tazobactam, but due to minimal ventilator requirements and neuromuscular weakness, spinal muscular atrophy, poliomyelitis, and myopathies were considered as possible factors. Investigations revealed areflexia, marked hypotonia, reduced power in all four limbs, and severe axonal and demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy. She was diagnosed with Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) and given two doses of intravenous immunoglobulin at 1g/kg/day. The patient required tracheostomy for prolonged ventilation and attained age-appropriate milestones on follow-up one month after discharge.

Hospital Course Details:
The patient presented with cough, loose stools, breathing difficulty, and listlessness. She had received DPT vaccine 25 days prior to admission. Chest examination revealed bilateral crepitations. A detailed neuromuscular examination revealed areflexia, marked hypotonia, and reduced power in all four limbs. Chest X-ray was normal. Investigations revealed hemoglobin 9.2 g/dL, white blood count 15,200/cum, neutrophil - 62%, lymphocytes - 32%, platelet count - 288000/cmm, C-reactive protein - 1.08 mg/L, and procalcitonin - 0.27 ng/ml. Serum potassium was 3.70 mmol/L, and serum calcium was 9.03 mg/dL. Creatine phosphokinase was 46 U/L. Nerve conduction velocity showed absent compound muscle action potential (CMAP) and sensory nerve action potential. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) was acellular with protein - 146.3 mg/dL. Stool specimen for polio virus isolation and SMN gene studies were sent.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
GBS was diagnosed based on the symptoms, neuromuscular examination, nerve conduction velocity, and CSF analysis. The patient was given two doses of intravenous immunoglobulin at 1g/kg/day. She required tracheostomy for prolonged ventilation, along with intravenous medication. 

Prognosis:
The patient showed gradual improvement in all limbs, and the tracheostomy tube was decannulated before discharge. Follow-up after one month revealed the patient was doing well and had obtained age-appropriate milestones. 

Discharge Summary:
The 5-month-old girl was admitted to the hospital with symptoms including cough, loose stools, breathing difficulty, and listlessness. She was diagnosed with Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) based on the neuromuscular symptoms and analysis of nerve conduction velocity and CSF. The patient was given two doses of intravenous immunoglobulin at 1g/kg/day and required tracheostomy for prolonged ventilation. Upon discharge, she showed gradual improvement of the limbs and achieved age-appropriate milestones. Follow-up after one month showed considerable improvement with no complications.

Diagnosis: Tumor-associated TTP complicated by acute non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was admitted to the Department of Gastroenterology with abdominal pain and pyrexia. He was later diagnosed with a villous adenoma (high-grade intraepithelial neoplasia) and deteriorated erosion in the corpus ventriculi. Preliminary laboratory findings showed a threshold of renal dysfunction, a moderately increased level of lactate dehydrogenase, and tumor marker CA125.

After 2 days, the patient developed nocturnal dyspnea and hyperpyrexia, including signs of dysphoria, perspiration, orthopnea, and pulmonary moist rales. Arterial pressure was 123/89 mm Hg. Emergent blood analysis showed an upsurge of indirect bilirubin, hepatic enzyme, and myocardial enzyme, as well as creatinine. Moreover, leukocytes began to increase, while platelets declined. The patient was then transferred to the Coronary Care Unit.

The cardiologists noted an alteration in the patient's appearance, with haziness, dysphoria or coma being observed. He occasionally complained of headache, fatigue or nausea. Delirium, petechiae and mild jaundice were exhibited successively. Laboratory tests showed that the comprehensive myocardial enzymes release curve matched with a typical MI. Thereafter, the hematocytes diminished (except leukocytes which increased), erythrocytes reduced to 2.93 × 1012/l, hemoglobin to 86 mg/dl and the platelet count to 8 × 109/l at a minimum. Moderate occult blood was detected in routine urinalysis. The peripheral blood smear showed schistocytes.

We logically proposed the final diagnosis of ‘tumor-associated TTP complicated by acute non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction’. As a result, the patient was treated with regular plasma transfusion in collaboration with steroids (methylprednisolone) and continuous renal replacement therapy.

The general condition of the patient improved remarkably. Consciousness was regained and symptoms were relieved. After 20 days in intensive care, the patient was discharged but depended on periodical continuous renal replacement therapy.

Follow-Up:

At 1-month follow-up, the illness was stable.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED] 

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: 11 April 2020

Date of Discharge: 28 April 2020

Reason for Admission: Acute-Onset dyspnea, Suspected acute asthma attack

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 26-year-old male with a known case of asthma, presented to the Emergency Department (ED) at Faghihi hospital, Shiraz, Iran, with acute-onset dyspnea and a decrease in the level of consciousness. The patient was intubated due to severe hypoxia and respiratory distress and was diagnosed with SARS-COV2 pneumonia with bilateral patchy opacities in both lung fields. The patient received treatment with dexamethasone, Piperacillin/tazobactam, and prophylactic heparin. He was paralyzed with cisatracurium in addition to midazolam and propofol due to significant patient-ventilator asynchrony. During mechanical ventilation, there was a progressive development of thrombocytopenia, which was treated with intravenous immunoglobulin. Platelet counts remained low throughout hospitalization.

On 21 April 2020, the patient developed upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding associated with generalized abdominal pain with distension. Upper GI endoscopy was normal, and the abdominal CT showed hypoperfused areas in the posterior segment of the right (Rt.) hepatic lobe and the medial and lateral segments of the left (Lt.) lobe. Color Doppler Sonography (CDS) of the abdomen demonstrated the absence of flow in the portal vein, consistent with acute portal vein thrombosis. The patient received treatment with Enoxaparin and was discharged with oral warfarin.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient's respiratory condition improved, and he was extubated on 16 April 2020. At the time of discharge on 28 April 2020, the patient's platelet counts had returned to normal, and he was stable. The patient was advised to follow up with his primary care physician for future management and care.

Follow-up Recommendations:

Follow-up recommended with Primary Care Physician for further management and care.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with a diagnosis of schizophrenia, undifferentiated type with a history of mental illness for 14–15 years. He was initially started on risperidone, but due to an increase in random blood sugar levels, he was switched to trifluoperazine. Trihexyphenidyl, lorazepam, and metformin were added to his treatment regimen. After maintaining the above medications for 56 days, the patient presented with sweating, confused behavior, and incontinence. Examinations revealed decreased deep tendon reflexes and an indeterminate plantar response. His random blood sugar level was within normal range, but fasting and postprandial blood glucose levels were elevated. IV fluids were administered, and human mixtard insulin was started to manage the elevated blood glucose levels. Trifluoperazine was stopped when his serum potassium levels were found to be low. Aripiprazole was started, and the patient was discharged on it along with lorazepam and human mixtard insulin.

Summary:
A 40-year-old male patient with a long-standing history of mental illness was admitted with a diagnosis of schizophrenia, undifferentiated type. The patient presented with sweating, confused behavior, and incontinence. After examinations, trifluoperazine was stopped due to serum potassium levels falling below the required range. The patient was subsequently started on aripiprazole and human mixtard insulin. He was discharged on the prescribed medications mentioned above and advised to follow up with his healthcare provider.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]  Age: 18   Sex: Female

Admission Date: [REDACTED]     Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Clinical Indications: Pain in right mandibular region

Medical History: Not available

Hospital Course:

The 18-year-old female patient presented to the Department of Dentistry, PUC Minas, with a complaint of pain in the right mandibular region. The clinical examination revealed pulp vitality, absence of mobility, and probing depths of 8.0 mm at the mesiobuccal, 7.0 mm at the distobuccal, and 9.0 mm at midbuccal sites. Furthermore, intense bleeding, suppuration, and the presence of a gingival abscess were also observed. Radiographic examination revealed a radiopaque structure around the cervical region of the lower right first premolar. Surgical exploration was performed by means of a conventional gingivoperiosteal flap, which revealed the presence of endodontic pathology (EP) associated with extensive bone loss. After removal of anatomical alterations and assessment of the remaining supporting tissues, extraction of tooth 44 was indicated and conducted.

Diagnosis: Endodontic pathology (EP) associated with extensive bone loss

Management:

Surgical exploration was performed by means of a conventional gingivoperiosteal flap. Dental extraction of tooth 44 was indicated and conducted after removal of anatomical alterations.

Outpatient Follow-up:

The patient was discharged with instructions for appropriate postoperative care and follow-up with a dentist as necessary. The patient was also advised to maintain proper oral hygiene to prevent further dental pathologies.

Complications:

No complications were noted during the course of the patient's hospital stay.

Signed:
[REDACTED] (Attending Dentist)

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Admission Diagnosis:
The patient was admitted to the emergency department with acute onset chest and neck pain radiating to both arms and associated numbness. She was diagnosed with a localized dissection of the mid left circumflex coronary artery.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent an emergent coronary angiography that led to the discovery of a luminal compression of the coronary artery. Percutaneous balloon angioplasty and drug eluting stent placement were performed successfully. The patient improved clinically with resolution of chest pain and was subsequently discharged.

Discharge Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with a localized dissection of the mid left circumflex coronary artery, which was corrected by percutaneous balloon angioplasty and drug eluting stent placement.

Discharge Medications:
The patient was discharged on aspirin, prasugrel, metoprolol tartrate, amlodipine, and atorvastatin.

Follow-Up Instructions:
The patient should follow up with her primary care physician or cardiologist as recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 44-year-old female with a history of HIV positivity, chronic viral hepatitis B, and retinal necrosis, was admitted to the hospital due to nausea, vomiting, and paralysis of both lower extremities. Upon admission, the patient complained of general weakness and had a decreased muscle strength of both legs at GII. A laboratory examination showed a low CD4 count, high serum lactate level, and positive HBV DNA. A contrast CT scan of the abdomen showed a hepatic cyst.

The patient was diagnosed with lactic acidosis and stopped taking antiretroviral drugs. She was administered intravenous sodium bicarbonate infusion and conservative treatment. The symptoms of nausea and vomiting resolved on the third day of treatment while the symptoms of paralysis gradually improved from the tenth day of treatment. ABGA results and lactate levels gradually normalized, and the patient was discharged on the 14th day without any signs of lactic acidosis.

After discharge, the patient resumed antiretroviral medications with no recurrence of previous symptoms. Two months after discharge, the patient's serum lactate level was 4.8 mmol/L. The patient is still on antiretroviral therapy and is being followed up on an outpatient basis.

Diagnoses:

1. Lactic Acidosis
2. HIV Infection
3. Chronic Viral Hepatitis B
4. Retinal Necrosis

Medications on Discharge:

The patient resumed antiretroviral medications with the following regimen:
1. Lamivudine
2. Efavirenz
3. Lopinavir/Ritonavir

Follow-Up:

The patient is recommended to continue antiretroviral therapy and hepatitis B management under outpatient follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 52
Sex: Male

Medical History: Subtotal thyroidectomy 20 years prior

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for a generalized tonic clonic seizure. Medical evaluation found decreased levels of parathormone and calcium in his blood, along with extensive calcification of the basal ganglia on brain CT scans. This resulted in the diagnosis of acute symptomatic seizure. The patient underwent an electroencephalographic (EEG) examination which was normal, and no antiepileptic treatment was recommended. The underlying situation was managed by endocrinologists. 

Final Diagnosis: Acute symptomatic seizure 

Treatment: No antiepileptic treatment was recommended 

Follow-Up Care: The patient should have a follow-up appointment with an endocrinologist.

Summary of Hospitalization:
The patient was hospitalized with a diagnosis of acute symptomatic seizure due to low levels of parathormone and calcium. No antiepileptic treatment was recommended, and the underlying situation was managed by endocrinologists. A follow-up appointment with an endocrinologist was recommended.

Abbreviations used:
CT- computed tomography 
EEG- electroencephalographic

Discharge Summary:

This is a discharge summary for a 55-year-old male patient who was diagnosed with multiple myeloma, subtype IgG/lambda Durie-Salmon stage IIIA, while being treated for back pain at our hospital. The patient has a known history of hepatitis B virus (HBV) and is a carrier for more than 20 years. There is also a family history of multiple myeloma with the patient's elder brother being diagnosed in 2008.

The patient was started on a 3-week cycle of PCD (Bortezomib, Cyclophosphamide, and Dexamethasone) as chemotherapy treatment for multiple myeloma. Entecavir was given as prophylaxis against HBV reactivation, and HBV-DNA was monitored since the start of therapy. The patient tolerated chemotherapy well, and there were no significant adverse effects.

After 1 cycle of therapy, serum HBV-DNA was undetectable, and after 2 months, HBsAg turned negative. The patient completed 4 courses of PCD therapy and achieved stringent complete response (sCR) after which peripheral blood hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) were collected and the patient underwent high-dose chemotherapy followed by autologous HSC transplantation as consolidation treatment. The patient has remained in sCR 26 months post-initial diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

During therapy and follow-up, HBsAg continued to be negative, and HBV-DNA levels remained below detection limit. The patient should continue to receive regular follow-up care for proper management of multiple myeloma and the management of potential HBV reactivation.

Summary:

- 55-year-old male diagnosed with multiple myeloma, subtype IgG/lambda Durie-Salmon stage IIIA
- Known HBV carrier for more than 20 years, with family history of multiple myeloma
- Received 3-week cycle of PCD chemotherapy, with Entecavir as prophylaxis against HBV reactivation
- Achieved stringent complete response (sCR) after 4 courses of therapy
- Underwent autologous HSC transplantation as consolidation treatment
- HBsAg turned negative after 2 months and remained negative during follow-up care
- Regular follow-up care is recommended for proper management of multiple myeloma and for the prevention of HBV reactivation.
